description: Marianne Williamson, the self-help author, on Tuesday attempted to revive her on-again, off-again long-shot candidacy for the Democratic presidential nomination by calling on the party to reopen the competition during its August convention in Chicago.

title: A Jewish Teen’s Diary Recounts Pain and Resilience in a Nazi Ghetto
description: It has not had the impact of Anne Frank’s classic journal, but another teenager’s diary from World War II has long provided a vivid picture of the miseries of life in a Jewish ghetto and the striking ways its doomed inhabitants endured.

title: Cuomo, in New Ad, Blasts Pro-Palestinian Demonstrators and Hamas
description: Former Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo of New York is behind a new advertising campaign that condemns Hamas’s actions on Oct. 7 and takes aim at demonstrators who have protested Israel’s killing of civilians in Gaza.

title: A Seismic Supreme Court Decision
description: On Friday, the Supreme Court sharply limited the regulatory authority of federal agencies, upending 40 years of legal precedent in a ruling with broad implications for the environment.

title: Biden Will Sit for Interview on Friday With ABC News
description: President Biden will sit for an interview on Friday with the ABC News anchor George Stephanopoulos, his first in-depth appearance with a journalist since his shaky debate performance last week raised alarms among Democrats about his continued viability as a candidate.

title: After Thursday’s Debate, Conservative Media Finds It Hard Not to Gloat
description: In the hours after last week’s presidential debate, a video clip began circulating that featured Jill Biden gingerly helping her husband step down from the event’s stage.

title: Biden’s Lapses Are Said to Be Increasingly Common and Worrisome
description: In the weeks and months before President Biden’s politically devastating performance on the debate stage in Atlanta, several current and former officials and others who encountered him behind closed doors noticed that he increasingly appeared confused or listless, or would lose the thread of conversations.

title: Trump Continues to Delay Naming a Running Mate, Amid Biden Debate Fallout
description: President Biden’s disastrous debate performance has persuaded former President Donald J. Trump to continue to hold off on naming his running mate for now, prompting another round of speculation — including within his own team — about when he may announce his pick.

title: The Best Movies and TV Shows Coming to Netflix in July
description: Every month, Netflix adds movies and TV shows to its library. Here are our picks for some of July’s most promising new titles. (Note: Streaming services occasionally change schedules without giving notice. For more recommendations on what to stream, sign up for our Watching newsletter here.)

title: Supreme Court Rejects Challenge to Life Sentences for Juveniles in Arizona
description: Over the dissents of its three liberal members, the Supreme Court said on Tuesday that it would not hear an appeal from a juvenile offender in Arizona who was sentenced to life without the possibility of parole.

title: The Question President Biden Needs to Ask Himself. Now.
description: Immediately after Hamas invaded Israel on Oct. 7, I urged Israel to think about how to respond by asking itself one question: What does your worst enemy want you to do? Then do the opposite. Iran and Hamas wanted Israel to rush headlong into Gaza — without any plan or Palestinian partner for the morning after — and unfortunately, Israel did just that.

title: Restaurant Review: A Shawarma Stall Is the Stage for a Spice Virtuoso
description: For a long time, I thought of Lior Lev Sercarz as the chef who got away.

title: Yale’s New President Pushed Policing as Head of Stony Brook University
description: A few weeks before Yale announced that Maurie McInnis would be its new president, she narrowly avoided censure at Stony Brook University, which she led for four years.

title: Supreme Court’s Immunity Ruling Adds Major Hurdle for Georgia Trump Case
description: The Supreme Court’s momentous ruling Monday on presidential immunity will reshape the prosecution of Donald J. Trump in Georgia.

title: Bruce Bastian, a Founder of WordPerfect, Is Dead at 76
description: Bruce Bastian, a founder of the WordPerfect Corporation, whose word processor was the favored tool for writing during the early days of personal computing — and who later, after coming out as gay, renounced his Mormon faith and funded L.G.B.T.Q. causes — died on June 16 at his home in Palm Springs, Calif. He was 76.

title: Democrats Go Public With Panic About Biden Amid Fears of an Electoral Debacle
description: Follow the latest 2024 presidential polls.

title: What Changes Would a Far-Right Government Bring to France?
description: Jordan Bardella, the far-right National Rally leader who may become France’s next prime minister, has repeated the same basic promises since a snap election was called in France.

title: Macron’s Rivals Say They’ll Fix France’s Economy, but Economists Are Skeptical
description: One of the messages that helped propel the far-right National Rally to the brink of power in France’s parliamentary elections on Sunday — a once-unthinkable shift — is a common refrain in U.S. politics: It’s the economy, stupid.

title: With Fists and Knives, Mobs Attack Syrian Refugees in Turkey
description: Over the past two days, angry groups of men in a half-dozen cities in Turkey have turned on the Syrian refugees living among them, damaging their shops and cars and assaulting them with fists and knives.

title: Wednesday Briefing: President Biden’s Lapses Increase
description: President Biden appeared confused or listless in the weeks and months before his devastating debate performance last week, according to many who encountered him.

title: U.S. Awards $504 Million for ‘Tech Hubs’ in Overlooked Regions
description: The Biden administration awarded $504 million on Tuesday to a dozen projects across the country in a bid to transform communities that had been overlooked in the past into technological powerhouses.

title: Thousands Flee in Gaza as Israel Orders More Evacuations
description: Israel issued a new round of evacuation orders for a large swath of the southern Gaza Strip on Tuesday, sending thousands of Palestinians fleeing once again for relative safety.

title: Unlicensed Therapist Used Wife’s Credentials to See Patients, Records Show
description: For two years beginning in 2021, hundreds of patients received online therapy from someone they mistakenly thought was Peggy Randolph, a licensed social worker. As it turns out, state records show, the person hearing their innermost thoughts was actually Ms. Randolph’s wife — a person identified in court records only as T.R.

title: Meloni Condemns Fascist Nostalgia Amid Scandal in Her Party’s Youth Wing
description: Italy’s prime minister, Giorgia Meloni, urged leaders of her political party on Tuesday to reject antisemitism, racism and nostalgia for totalitarian regimes after an Italian news outlet caught on a hidden camera members of the youth section of her party glorifying fascism.

title: Biden’s Lapses Have Increased, According to Some Insiders
description: Like many other 81-year-old men, President Biden has sometimes mangled a sentence or mixed up a fact during his three and a half years in office. But in recent weeks, people who have spent time with the president said that his lapses appeared to have grown more frequent, more pronounced and more worrisome.

title: Why GPS Is Under Attack
description: Satellite signals run the modern world. See just how vulnerable they are.

title: Julián Castro, a 2020 Opponent of Biden, Says He Should Step Aside
description: Julián Castro, a former presidential candidate who ran against President Biden in the 2020 Democratic primaries, said on Tuesday that Mr. Biden should drop out of the race, pointing to Vice President Kamala Harris as a potential replacement at the top of the Democratic ticket.

title: Paramount and Skydance Near Merger Deal
description: For months, Paramount’s controlling shareholder and Skydance sought to seal a merger that would transform the media industry, before those talks ground to a sudden halt in June. Now, just weeks later, the two sides have reached a preliminary deal to merge, four people familiar with the negotiations said.

title: The Historical Echo Biden Has Tried to Suppress
description: More Democrats aired doubts about President Biden’s candidacy on Tuesday, the most public and direct voicing of concern since his disastrous debate performance on Thursday.

title: ‘Beverly Hills Cop: Axel F’ Review: It’s Busted
description: In “Beverly Hills Cop: Axel F,” the Detroit detective Axel Foley (Eddie Murphy) is no longer the fast, young cop we last saw 30 years ago. The beleaguered Captain Jeffrey Friedman (Paul Reiser) thinks the older and slower Axel should reconnect with his estranged daughter, Jane (Taylour Paige), who works as a defense attorney in Los Angeles. She is representing someone accused of killing a possible dirty cop. When masked men dangle Jane’s car with her inside from a roof, Axel, at the request of his longtime pal Billy Rosewood (Judge Reinhold), comes to Los Angeles to find the culprits.

title: What Would a Better Israeli Prime Minister Do?
description: A better Israeli prime minister than Benjamin Netanyahu would immediately hold an election. Israelis deserve a government they believe can bring them out of crisis, not one that got them into this crisis. If that government is still led by Netanyahu, at least he would have an honest mandate, and dissenting Israelis would have fewer reasons to protest him. It would also give the prime minister more authority over a military that seems to think that it can openly oppose the views of its civilian masters.

title: Lloyd Doggett, a Texas Progressive, Cracks the Democratic Dam for Biden
description: Representative Lloyd Doggett, a little-known Texas progressive, on Tuesday became the first Democrat in Congress to call on President Biden to step aside as the party’s nominee after a halting debate performance that has raised major questions about his health, age and mental acuity.

title: Palestinians Flee Khan Younis Following Israeli Evacuation Orders
description: Gazans who had already been forced to flee again and again were once more hauling their belongings out of eastern Khan Younis after the Israeli military’s new evacuation orders in southern Gaza.

title: New Haitian Leader Visits Washington Seeking Additional Support
description: Top Democrats in Congress met on Tuesday with Haiti’s newly installed prime minister, Garry Conille, and pledged to push for additional American assistance days after a U.S.-backed international police mission arrived on the Caribbean island to restore stability to a country that for months has been under siege by criminal gangs.

title: Robert Towne, Screenwriter of ‘Chinatown’ and More, Dies at 89
description: Robert Towne, whose screenplay for Roman Polanski’s “Chinatown” won an Oscar, and whose work on that and other important films established him as one of the leading screenwriters of the so-called New Hollywood, died on Monday at his home in Los Angeles. He was 89.

title: Acknowledging Debate Debacle, Biden Says He ‘Fell Asleep on the Stage’
description: President Biden acknowledged on Tuesday that he “fell asleep on the stage” during his disastrous debate last week, blaming his performance on the fact that he had traveled “around the world a couple times” in the two weeks before the face-off with former President Donald J. Trump.

title: Iran’s Runoff Election: What to Know
description: Two candidates, a reformist and an ultraconservative, will face off in Iran’s runoff presidential election on Friday, amid record-low voter turnout and overarching apathy that meaningful change could happen through the ballot box.

title: What to See in N.Y.C. Galleries in July
description: This week in Newly Reviewed, Will Heinrich covers the group show “Patterns” at two Luhring Augustine locations and five new sculptures by Virginia Overton at Bortolami.

title: Two Vulnerable House Democrats Say Biden Will Lose Against Trump
description: Follow the latest 2024 presidential polls.

title: Special Counsel Is Said to Be Planning to Pursue Trump Cases Past the Election
description: Judge Aileen Cannon dismisses classified documents case against Trump. Follow live updates.

title: Nordic Toast
description: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues

title: Women in India Face a Jobs Crisis. Are Factories the Solution?
description: Before her husband died, leaving her to raise their 2-year-old daughter alone, Sarika Pawar had never imagined working a regular job. Like her own mother and most of the women she knew in rural India, she spent her days confined to her village. Her hours were consumed with looking after her toddler, boiling water to drink and fashioning an evening meal.

title: Investors Pour $27.1 Billion Into A.I. Start-Ups, Defying a Downturn
description: For two years, many unprofitable tech start-ups have cut costs, sold themselves or gone out of business. But the ones focused on artificial intelligence have been thriving.

title: An Uproar Over a Chinese Doping Case, Except in China
description: In past years, when athletes from China have been accused of doping, the government has mobilized its propaganda apparatus of state-owned newspapers, television commentators and social media accounts to defend the athletes and deflect criticism of China’s sports system.

title: Wednesday Briefing
description: President Biden appeared confused or listless in the weeks and months before his devastating debate performance last week, according to current and former officials who said that the lapses seemed to be growing more frequent, more pronounced and more worrisome.

title: China Seizes Taiwanese Fishing Boat in Latest Uptick in Tensions
description: China’s Coast Guard has seized a Taiwanese fishing boat and its crew of five and forced it to a port on the mainland Chinese coast, a move that could add to tensions between Beijing and President Lai Ching-te of Taiwan.

title: Britain’s Next Prime Minister Has Shown Us Who He Is, and It’s Not Good
description: The outcome seems predestined. The British Conservative Party, moribund after 14 years in office and struggling to defend its record of routine corruption and economic mismanagement, is heading into Thursday’s general election with the backing of just 20 percent of the electorate. The opposition Labour Party, having run a colorless campaign whose main aim was to channel frustration with the government, is projected to win a huge parliamentary majority. That means that Labour’s leader, Keir Starmer, will be the country’s next prime minister.

title: Competitive Eaters Are Just Like Us. Give or Take a Dozen Hot Dogs.
description: Day to day, Julie Goldberg eats in a manner that could be described as “exceedingly normal.” She finishes her salad. She does not eat her pizza crust. You’d have no idea that Ms. Goldberg, 38, is a competitive eater in training to eat, if not the most hot dogs in history, then the most hot dogs that she has eaten in her life.

title: Why America’s Adversaries Are Wrong About the Biden-Trump Debate
description: Hours after the presidential debate, Vladimir Putin’s spokesman, Dmitri Peskov, said that his boss didn’t bother to watch. Mr. Peskov even scoffed at the notion: The Russian president could hardly be expected to set his alarm to watch the broadcast in the middle of the night in Moscow. In any case, he added, the debate was America’s internal affair. But judging by the wave of propaganda that immediately followed on Russian television, Mr. Putin was, indeed, paying attention.

title: They Came for Spiritual Revival, Only to Be Trapped in a Deadly Panic
description: One moment, a crowd of tens of thousands, almost all women, were singing and swaying in devotion to a revered holy man in front of them onstage, all packed under a sprawling tent in northern India.

title: How China and Russia Compete, and Cooperate, in Central Asia
description: With Russia mired in a long war in Ukraine and increasingly dependent on China for supplies, Beijing is moving quickly to expand its sway in Central Asia, a region that was once in the Kremlin’s sphere of influence.

title: Hurricane Beryl Caused ‘Unimaginable’ Damage in Grenada, Leader Says
description: As Hurricane Beryl headed toward Jamaica and the Cayman Islands early Wednesday as a powerful Category 4 storm, a clearer picture emerged of the devastation it had caused on two small islands in Grenada, with that country’s leader calling the destruction “unimaginable” and “total.”

title: New Jersey Is One of America’s Fastest-Warming States, Data Shows
description: New Jersey is heating up faster than any other state in the Northeast, pacing a region with rapidly rising temperatures, according to data gathered by a nonprofit research organization.

title: New York City’s Worst Water Bill Delinquent? New York State.
description: When Mayor Eric Adams of New York declared that he would shut off water service to nonpaying customers, he cast the effort as a fight against big landlords bilking city taxpayers.

title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.

title: U.S. Deports Chinese Migrants in First Large Flight Since 2018
description: The United States sent a group of migrants back to China on the first large deportation flight there since 2018, and said on Tuesday that it was working with Chinese authorities to arrange additional flights.

title: Fourth of July Will Be a Scorcher for Most of the U.S.
description: The Fourth of July is known for sweaty backyard barbecues, scorching Major League Baseball day games, and, if you’re lucky, cooler nighttime temperatures as fireworks finally pop after sunset.

title: How to Choose the Right Tour Group
description: Tour companies that offer multiday trips arrange most everything for you: lodging, sightseeing, food and transportation. But group size, style of travel and budget are among the considerations travelers should assess before picking a tour. Read on for tips.

title: A Ban on Elephant Hunting Has Collapsed. Or Maybe It Never Existed.
description: On the lush, rolling savannas that link northern Tanzania to Amboseli National Park in Kenya, foraging elephants move back and forth on a sloping landscape in the shadow of snow-capped Mount Kilimanjaro.

title: 4 New Audiobook Memoirs for Music Lovers
description: Nobody said it was easy being a rock star. Actually, people do say that, perhaps most unforgettably Dire Straits in their 1985 hit “Money for Nothing.” But musicians have become much more open about their challenges, as a recent spate of memoirs can attest.

title: America’s Divided Summer Economy Is Coming to an Airport or Hotel Near You
description: The travel industry is in the midst of another hot summer as Americans hit the road and make for the airport to take advantage of slightly cheaper flights and gas. But the 2024 vacation outlook isn’t all sunny: Like the rest of the American consumer experience this year, it is sharply divided.

title: How Do You Restore a Chestnut Forest or an Apple Orchard? Very Slowly.
description: “Explore what’s in bloom now,” exclaims a banner on the New England Botanic Garden at Tower Hill’s website. And, indeed, there is much to see.

title: Our Favorite Nutrition Takeaways From 2024, So Far
description: If you’re looking to freshen up your food habits, summer is the season to do it. Farmers’ markets are overflowing. Backyard grills are firing. Picnic blankets are unfurling. And school pickups have slowed to a halt, giving us more time to cook and enjoy relaxed outdoor meals with friends.

title: A British Literary Festival Fit for a Queen
description: In 1603, the newly christened King’s Men acting troupe took up a Christmas residency at Hampton Court Palace. Every night, the company — best known for its master playwright William Shakespeare — would celebrate the holidays and the ascendancy of its patron, King James I, with a production of one of Shakespeare’s plays, including a New Year’s performance of the romantic fairy romp “A Midsummer Night’s Dream.”

title: The Most Intriguing Animated Films You’ll Never See
description: Among fans of canceled animated film projects — and yes, there is such a fandom, and it’s enormous — “Me and My Shadow” is perhaps the most popular cartoon feature that never was.

title: Two Kings Battle for a Millennium-Old Throne in Nigeria
description: One king has been barricaded in the palace, protected from potential usurpers by hundreds of subjects armed with sticks and machetes.

title: The Secret Lives of Gulls
description: As you enjoy a summer day at the beach, you’re likely to encounter gulls. These bold birds are notorious for snatching food from unsuspecting sunbathers, but there’s more to them than meets the eye. Jim Gorman, a writer for The New York Times Science desk, delves into the complex behavior of gulls, which are not only expert thieves but also devoted parents and keen observers of human activity.

title: San Francisco’s Arts Institutions Are Slowly Building Back
description: On a recent clear day, visitors were wandering through the San Francisco Museum of Modern Art to gawk at works by Yayoi Kusama and Alexander Calder, and, a few blocks away, making their way through the galleries at the Contemporary Jewish Museum and the Museum of the African Diaspora.

title: ‘This Closeness’ Review: So Near, So Far Away
description: City living presupposes closeness. Even when you’re alone in your apartment, dozens of people are likely to be sitting, cooking, napping, fighting or having sex within feet of you, separated by walls that are usually way too thin. But to live an urban life without getting overstimulated requires developing an artificial sense of distance, the ability to be alone in public, to ignore others while maintaining a sense of alertness. A pair of noise-canceling headphones. A bit of tunnel vision.

title: The Secret Behind a Beloved Palestinian Dessert
description: Take a handful of tears. This is not an attempt at poetry: They are, in fact, called tears, these tiny, translucent fragments of resin, glittering like sugar and giving off the scent of high, sweet pine. The fragrance is the flavor. They come from inside a mastic tree, an evergreen cousin to the pistachio, that abounds in the Mediterranean and the Middle East and thrives in difficult soil, in the sandy remains of crushed rock, where less hardy plants might wither. Once rooted, fed by the sun, the trees can go for long stretches without water — without any care at all.

title: The Conservatives Have Run Britain for 14 Years. How Has That Worked Out?
description: The metrics that British voters say matter the most offer a portrait of decline.

title: The Real Problem With Legal Weed
description: When New York legalized recreational marijuana in 2021, the future seemed bright. “It has been a long road to get here, but it will be worth the wait,” State Senator Liz Krueger, a sponsor of the legislation, told New Yorkers. Legalization, she and others said, meant a wave of new jobs and new tax revenue. It meant an end to racist policing of marijuana and the start of equity, with rules that put those harmed by prohibition at the front of the line for licenses. And it meant easy-to-buy weed for the 1.6 million adult New Yorkers who already partook.

title: New York Expands Divisive Food Debit Card Program for Migrants
description: Good morning. It’s Wednesday. Today we’ll look at the expansion of a city pilot program to give food debit cards to migrants. The program will cost the city $2.6 million, which officials said was cheaper than providing boxed meals.

title: 5 Minutes That Will Make You Love Wayne Shorter
description: This month we feature Wayne Shorter, the iconoclastic composer and tenor saxophonist whose work with Art Blakey, Miles Davis, Weather Report and through his own solo discography has influenced generations of like-minded visionaries to push the boundaries of jazz. Since his death in 2023 at 89, it’s felt like he’s still around. That’s because his music always felt so otherworldly and progressive, as if it were beamed in from outer space or somewhere deep into the future.

title: The Bleak, Nihilistic Show Russians Can’t Stop Watching
description: In December, the Ukrainian culture ministry issued a warning about a Russian TV series that was being widely (and illegally) viewed across the besieged nation. There was no explicit mention of the offending show, which was described as “hostile propaganda,” but none was needed: Everyone knew it was “Slovo Patsana: Krov na Asphalte,” a new series about the youth gangs, or gruppirovki, that came to dominate the central Russian city Kazan in the final years of the Soviet Union.

title: Our Favorite Relationship Advice of 2024, So Far
description: Romantic relationships can be a source of deep joy and satisfaction — and also a real pain to navigate.

title: $550,000 Homes in Maine, the District of Columbia and Kentucky
description: This property is in a town that is home to about 1,300 full-time residents and the Maine Maritime Academy, a four-year college from which many students go on to join the United States merchant marine. It is about five minutes from several small inns and waterfront restaurants, a pub, two grocery stores and Wadsworth Cove Beach. Hatch Cove Preserve, a popular spot for bird-watching, is also nearby.

title: Back When Women Were Told to ‘Write Like a Man’
description: “Write Like a Man”: The title of Ronnie Grinberg’s group portrait of the midcentury New York intellectuals sounds both confrontational and comic, aggressive and anachronistic. What used to be considered a compliment (albeit an inherently chauvinistic one) now sounds so ridiculous that it can only be an ironic joke. The transformation is a mark of how much has changed since the moment Grinberg writes about, when a cohort of writers clustered around small but influential journals like Partisan Review and Dissent made virtues out of intellectual provocation and polemical combat.

title: Paul Theroux on Necessary Solitude, Risks and the Joy of Writing
description: The Unstoppables is a series about people whose ambition is undimmed by time. Below, Paul Theroux explains, in his own words, what continues to motivate him.

title: How a Patriotic Painting Became the Internet’s Soapbox
description: So you have an opinion you want to share online — something you need to get off your chest. Maybe it’s about the current political climate. Maybe you want to have the final word on whether or not people should wear their shoes in the house.

title: Architects of the Trump Supreme Court See Culmination of Conservative Push
description: Back in 2016, a colleague handed Donald F. McGahn II, then a top legal adviser to the presidential candidate Donald J. Trump, an appeals court opinion that eloquently and powerfully echoed much of what Mr. McGahn saw as the evils of an out-of-control federal bureaucracy.

title: Niclas Larsson Is Ready to Shoot More Close-Ups
description: If old age is not for snowflakes — well, try directing a 90-minute feature film about old age in the iPhone era, as Niclas Larsson has done.

title: A French Museum Collides With New Jersey Politics
description: Plans to build an outpost of the Pompidou Center in the heart of Jersey City were put on hold after the State Legislature voted last week to rescind $24 million in funding for the Paris museum’s project.

title: Doing Nothing About Biden Is the Riskiest Plan of All
description: After last week’s debate disaster, some Democrats are trying to circle the wagons to protect President Biden, noting that Barack Obama lost his first debate as an incumbent president, too.

title: In Immunity Decision, Clashing Views of the Nature of Politics
description: Near the end of his opinion on executive immunity, Chief Justice John G. Roberts Jr. pooh-poohed the fears of his liberal colleagues who worried in dissent that the broad protections the Supreme Court had conferred on former President Donald J. Trump would place future presidents beyond the reach of the law.

title: Some People Love ‘The Bear’ … for Its Style
description: The hit FX series “The Bear” is about many things: complicated family dynamics, grief, toxic workplace environments, Chicago, vocational obsession and, of course, food. But for some people, it’s really just a show about clothes set in and around a Chicago restaurant.

title: What Voters in France and Britain Really Want
description: Political observers crave a narrative — the more global, the better. And as the U.S. election descends into a state of chaos, American liberals looking across the Atlantic for some sense of context will see alarms flashing red. In France, a snap National Assembly election has delivered a distressing first-round victory for Marine Le Pen, long the bête noire of European liberalism, and a humiliating defeat for President Emmanuel Macron, almost a caricature of the continental elite.

title: The ‘Philly Girl’ Shielding Biden From the Bad News
description: Amid the public fretting and finger-pointing rage over how to deal with a Democratic presidential nominee who most Americans think is too old for the job, some of the frustration is being directed at the first lady, Jill Biden. Which has me thinking back to one of the viral moments from her husband’s 2020 campaign.

title: A Dismissed Abortion Case Points to Internal Tensions and Dysfunction at the Supreme Court
description: Given the breathtaking sweep of the Supreme Court’s decisions in the final days of its term, it’s easy to overlook a decision that had no sweep at all because it was a decision not to decide.

title: Biden’s Team Scrambles to Contain First Democratic Defections
The Health Trends That Are Defining 2024
description: I’m Dani Blum, a reporter on the Well desk, filling in for Jancee Dunn today. Part of my job is making sense of the endless array of wellness trends that take over the internet. Some days, that means chasing down the answers to age-old questions; other days, I’m investigating new products.

title: Big Donors Turn on Biden. Quietly.
description: Wealthy Democratic donors who believe a different nominee would be the party’s best chance to hold the White House are increasingly gritting their teeth in silence about President Biden, fearful that any move against him could backfire.

title: The Man Behind the Minions
description: When the French animation studio Illumination was developing “Despicable Me,” an ingratiating family comedy about a second rate supervillain and his adopted children, the team decided that the movie needed some lighthearted relief to help make the movie’s antihero, Gru (Steve Carell), more sympathetic.

title: Quotation of the Day: In Factories, India’s Women See a Lifeline
description: “When you come out of your house, you see the outside world. You see the possibilities, and I feel that we can make progress.”

title: You See a Hedge. He Sees Something Else.
description: When Tim Bushe decided to trim some hedges one recent evening, he attracted more attention than usual for a routine garden chore.

title: An Israeli air base is a source of GPS ‘spoofing’ attacks, researchers say.
description: Researchers at the University of Texas at Austin have identified an Israeli air base as a key source of GPS attacks that have disrupted civilian airline navigation in the Middle East.

title: How to Handle Crowded Airports and Roads This Fourth of July
description: Whether they’re driving or flying, people traveling for the upcoming holiday weekend are expected to break records in what is already one of the busiest years yet for travel.

title: The Connections Companion No. 389, July 4, 2024
description: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.

title: Wordle Review No. 1,111, July 4, 2024
description: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

title: A Look at Biden’s Lapses, and a Holdup in Trump’s Sentencing
description: On Today’s Episode:

title: The American Journalist on Trial in Russia
description: Evan Gershkovich, an American journalist for The Wall Street Journal, was detained in Russia more than a year ago. He has been locked up in a high-security prison and accused of spying for the U.S. government.

title: The British Election
description: Britain goes to the polls tomorrow after a campaign that featured the same ingredients as other elections across Europe and the Americas: frustrated voters eager to reject the status quo, a deeply discredited government and a dash of populism — in this case, represented by the insurgent candidacy of Nigel Farage.

title: U.S. Allies See a Worrisome Turn in Presidential Immunity Ruling
description: Allies of the United States had already been looking at the country’s upcoming election with anxiety. Now, with the United States Supreme Court granting an unprecedented expansion of executive power by giving presidents legal immunity, analysts in some of those countries are even more concerned about the reliability of American power.

title: British Teenager’s Disappearance Spurs Speculation and Sleuthing
description: When a young British man disappeared while vacationing on the Spanish island of Tenerife in mid-June, a familiar routine unfolded: search and rescue workers combing through the landscape, regular updates from tearful family members, a steady drumbeat of unconfirmed reports that he had been spotted.

title: If Not President Biden, Then Who?
description: The Biden campaign’s attempts to soothe panicked Democrats and donors after the president’s calamitous debate appear to have cratered.

title: Word of the Day: sociable
description: The word sociable has appeared in 26 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Sept. 5 in “5 Hot Springs in Iceland That Aren’t the Blue Lagoon” by Lisa Abend:

title: Apartments Are Growing in Size. Here’s Where They’re Largest.
description: Tiny homes are being built across the country, and novel approaches to living small are being explored around the globe. For much of the past decade, the average size of a newly built rental apartment in the United States had also been shrinking. But recently the trend reversed. In 2023, the average size of new rentals increased by 27 square feet, to 916 from 889, according to a study by RentCafe.

title: How Can I Tell My Elderly Mother That She Can’t Live With Me?
description: I am nearly 60 and newly divorced. My mother is 83 and has multiple health issues: She can barely walk and has profound deafness. She lives alone on a modest budget in a large house that needs repair. I live and work 200 miles away. I am moving into a small apartment until I get back on my feet after my divorce. A local friend runs errands for my mother, and I manage her finances. We don’t have any close relatives. Fortunately, she has begrudgingly agreed with her doctor, her friend and me that she can no longer live alone. She plans to sell her house, but she is burying me in guilt that I won’t let her live with me. I love her, but I can’t become her full-time caregiver now. I need to rebuild my life, but I feel terrible saying no. She would take me in without hesitation if our situations were reversed. Help!

title: Think Twice Before Lighting Fireworks This July 4
description: For many people, nothing says July 4 like fireworks.

title: Are We in the Middle of a Spiritual Awakening?
description: When I asked readers who identified as spiritual but not religious to reach out to me, I was astounded by how much variety there was in the faith experiences of individuals in this group. Some said they found spirituality both in the beauty of the physical world and in communing with other people.

title: How to Clean Up Your Phone’s Photo Library to Free Up Space
description: Are you getting ominous warnings about your phone’s storage? Have you ever whipped out your phone to show someone a certain photo and had to scroll for minutes to find it? If you’ve accumulated gigabytes of images over the years, streamlining your photo library and dumping other unnecessary apps and files can let you reclaim that space. Here’s a guide to doing just that by using free tools that are probably already on your phone.

title: An Artist Who Turned Her Bedroom Closet Into a Safe Haven
description: At 52 Walker in New York, Diamond Stingily’s site-specific installations tell a story of desire, shame and coming-of-age.

title: Biden to Hold Crisis Meeting With Democratic Governors at the White House
description: President Biden is scheduled to meet on Wednesday with several Democratic governors in a closed-door meeting at the White House, part of a push to reassure the president’s supporters that he can still win the election in November despite his debate debacle last week.

title: The Wide, Wide World of Judy Chicago
description: Like all women and all art, Judy Chicago contains multitudes. This summer, the 84-year old American artist’s lifelong interest in excavating and subverting female history through storytelling, activism and overtly feminine aesthetics and materials is on display in two bold and affecting European retrospectives.

title: ‘Space Cadet’ Review: Emma Roberts Shoots for the Stars
description: Some of Hollywood’s most durable genre conventions have to do with outsiders and underdogs, often two categories rolled into one, who show up the self-important elites. The cowboy who rolls into town and brings justice in a not-quite-law-abiding way. The lovable con artist who makes a fool of the uppity society folks. The washed-up cop or spy called in for one last covert mission. The stereotypical sorority girl who turns out to be a secret legal genius.

title: 4 Books to Read This Summer
description: A New York Times Book Review editor recommends four books for the summer.

title: A Family Loses 3 Generations of Women in India Crowd’s Panic
description: Vinod Kumar was away from home on Tuesday, as he usually is for days at a time in search of masonry work, when he got the dreadful call.

title: Biden Tells Allies He Knows He Has Only Days to Salvage Candidacy
description: President Biden has told key allies that he knows the coming days are crucial and understands that he may not be able to salvage his candidacy if he cannot convince voters that he is up to the job after a disastrous debate performance last week.

title: 26,000 Evacuate as Wildfire Spreads in Northern California
description: When a fast-moving wildfire began marching across thousands of acres of Butte County on Tuesday, David Pittman didn’t panic. He packed up his family, including their 90-pound African sulcata tortoise, and drove to his sister’s house across town in Oroville, Calif.

title: This Bigheaded Fossil Turned Up in a Place No One Expected to Find It
description: Some 280 million years ago, a large predator glided through the chilly waters of a  supercontinent in the Southern Hemisphere. The eight-foot-long hunter had tiny limbs, an eel-like body and a flat head full of jutting fangs. And according to existing ideas about vertebrate evolution, it shouldn’t have existed.

title: How the Denisovans Survived the Ice Age
description: The Baishiya Karst Cave is not an easy place to call home. It is nestled on a steep rocky slope on the Tibetan Plateau, 10,700 feet up, where the oxygen is thin and the climate cold and dry.

title: Pizza Flavors Without Pizza Temperatures
description: We’ve had pizza on the brain here at The New York Times food section, ever since Brett Anderson published his excellent, deep dive into the culture of American pizza-making, along with our list of 22 of the best pizzas in the country. What are your favorites?

title: A Group of Business Leaders Call on Biden to Step Aside
description: A group of business leaders is calling on President Biden to step aside and make way for a replacement atop the Democratic Party’s presidential ticket.

title: How Reliant Is the U.S. on Avocados From Mexico?
description: Americans have a growing appetite for avocados, and a single state in Mexico supplies nearly all of the fruit eaten in the United States.

title: Heritage Foundation Head Refers to ‘Second American Revolution’
description: The president of the Heritage Foundation, a right-wing think tank that has developed a prominent series of policy plans to overhaul the federal government under a Republican president, said on Tuesday that the country was “in the process of the second American Revolution, which will remain bloodless if the left allows it to be.”

title: Packing for Camp? Leave Your Sephora Hauls at Home.
description: This year will be Zoe Oosting’s seventh summer at the Rockbrook Summer Camp for Girls in western North Carolina, where campers, ages 6 to 16, ride horses through the mountains, spin slabs of clay and weave friendship bracelets.

title: Can I Say I Have Tourette’s Without Being Formally Diagnosed?
description: I’m in my 30s and have multiple motor and vocal tics that started in my early teens and have never gone away. As far as I can tell, I fit the diagnostic criteria for Tourette’s syndrome. My tics have gotten worse as I’ve gotten older, but while I tic pretty frequently in private, my tics are only minimally apparent in public (at most a sudden head jerk here and there, which most people just pretend not to see). My tics do not cause me sufficient physical or social distress to prompt me to get medical treatment for them. It doesn’t seem worth seeking out a formal diagnosis, which might require investing a lot of money  and time in the American medical system, when I’m not looking for treatment.

title: Did You Find These Easter Eggs in ‘The Bear’?
description: In its third season, “The Bear,” a television show known for its dedicated hyperrealism, did not disappoint fans looking for real-world culinary references. As Carmy (Jeremy Allen White), Sydney (Ayo Edebiri) and their team of former sandwich professionals hustled for a Michelin star or two at their newly opened fine-dining spot, Easter eggs dotted the show. We’ve compiled a short list, with help from restaurant industry professionals, of the most true-to-life nods and hidden surprises:

title: Crafting a Wardrobe by America’s Finest Artisans
description: “It started with me stalking a nun with a cashmere goat farm,” said Melissa Ventosa Martin, the founder of Old Stone Trade, an online marketplace for wares made by international artisans.

title: V. Craig Jordan, Who Discovered a Key Breast Cancer Drug, Dies at 76
description: V. Craig Jordan, a pharmacologist whose discovery that a failed contraceptive, tamoxifen, could block the growth of breast cancer cells opened up a whole new class of drugs and helped save the lives of millions of women, died on June 9 at his home in Houston. He was 76.

title: Repeated Evacuation Orders Take Toll on Already Weakened Gazans
description: An evacuation order by the Israeli military this week covering roughly a third of the Gaza Strip came as people there are less and less equipped to handle repeated forced displacements, after nearly nine months of war that have left tens of thousands dead and injured and put the territory at risk of famine.

title: Democrats in Congress Weigh Whether to Stick With Biden
description: Democratic leaders in the House and Senate refrained on Wednesday from urging their members to rally around President Biden and were instead listening to a barrage of complaints streaming in from both the party’s centrist wing and its progressives.

title: Destruction on Carriacou and Petite Martinique Islands Captured in Satellite Images
description: As Hurricane Beryl churns toward Jamaica, the islands devastated in its path reckoned with the scale of the destruction on Wednesday.

title: If Biden Doesn’t Run, Nominate …
description: To the Editor:

title: How Would the Restaurant in ‘The Bear’ Work in Real Life?
description: This article discusses scenes from the beginning through the end of FX’s “The Bear” Season 3, now available in full on Hulu.

title: Biden Campaign Memos Show Efforts to Calm Concerns
description: The Biden campaign sent out a pair of memos on Wednesday — one to staff members and another to Congressional Democrats — attempting to quell concerns about President Biden’s struggling re-election effort as a growing chorus of Democrats publicly vented its frustrations and fears that he could lose in November.

title: Are You a Checker or an Unchecker?
description: Last week, Nolen Royalty unleashed upon the world a website with a million empty check boxes.

title: What Is a Sundress?
description: A heated discussion about one of the summer's most ubiquitous garments grapples with questions of femininity, tradition and sexuality. Weigh in on the debate.

title: G.M. Sold Millions of Cars That Were More Polluting Than Allowed, E.P.A. Says
description: The Biden administration has reached a settlement with General Motors after determining that the automaker sold nearly six million cars that emitted more planet-warming carbon dioxide than the company had claimed, violating federal regulations.

title: ‘A Roller Coaster in a Carwash’: Why Scientists Are Flying Into Hurricane Beryl
description: Hurricane Beryl, which devastated islands in Grenada on Tuesday and is now heading toward Jamaica and the Cayman Islands, has broken records as the earliest hurricane ever to reach Category 4 and Category 5 intensity in the Atlantic Basin. Wind speeds of at least 160 miles per hour were recorded on Monday.

title: How a Fractured Supreme Court Ruled this Term
description: The Supreme Court has had a volatile term, taking on a stunning array of major disputes and assuming a commanding role in shaping American society and democracy. Adam Liptak and Abbie VanSickle, supreme court reporters at The New York Times, explain how a season of blockbuster cases defined the court.

title: Cross-Tabs: July 2024 Times/Siena Poll of the Likely Electorate
description: Results of a nationwide New York Times/Siena College poll conducted among 1,532 likely voters from June 28 to July 2, 2024.

title: Cross-Tabs: July 2024 Times/Siena Poll of Registered Voters Nationwide
description: Results of a nationwide New York Times/Siena College poll conducted among 1,532 registered voters from June 28 to July 2, 2024.

title: Toplines: July 2024 Times/Siena Poll of Registered Voters Nationwide
description: Results of a nationwide New York Times/Siena College poll conducted among 1,532 registered voters from June 28 to July 2, 2024.

title: Trump Widens Lead After Biden’s Debate Debacle, Times/Siena Poll Finds
description: Donald J. Trump’s lead in the 2024 presidential race has widened after President Biden’s fumbling debate performance last week, as concerns that Mr. Biden is too old to govern effectively rose to new heights among Democrats and independent voters, a new poll from The New York Times and Siena College showed.

title: The Debate Hurt Biden, but the Real Shift Has Been Happening for Years
description: In the wake of the first presidential debate, a chorus of top Biden allies and campaign officials has advanced a simple message: The race has not fundamentally changed.

title: Cayman Islands Prepare for Hurricane Beryl
description: Preparations were underway for the arrival of Hurricane Beryl in the Cayman Islands, where the storm was expected to move through Wednesday night.

title: What’s in Our Queue? ‘One Day’ and More
description: I’m a national political reporter covering the presidential election. Here are five things I’ve recently delighted in seeing, hearing and watching.

title: ‘The Bear’ Gets a Glow Up. Is That a Good Thing?
description: The trajectory of FX’s “The Bear” has mirrored the fortunes of its characters. Over three seasons, what started as a scrappy half-hour comedy about a band of gritty Chicagoans running a sandwich shop has now become a cultural phenomenon about those same characters running a fancy restaurant — in suits and Thom Browne chef’s whites, no less.

title: Jamaican Airports Shut Down, Stranding Travelers and Snarling Plans
description: All three of Jamaica’s international airports closed late Tuesday as Hurricane Beryl churned toward the island, leaving some travelers stranded and others scrambling to adjust their plans.

title: There’s a Name for the Trap Biden Faces
description: After his shockingly poor performance in last week’s debate, President Biden is facing mounting pressure to drop out of the 2024 election. Influential voices in his own party have called for him to step aside. Polls indicate that many voters hope he will. Yet so far, he is staying the course.

title: The Best Beach Umbrella Is Not Actually an Umbrella
description: It's a sunshade.

title: What’s Better Than S’mores? A Giant S’mores Tart
description: I never was a Girl Scout, so I came late to s’mores. I was already a teenager when I squished my first blackened marshmallow between graham crackers and chocolate after awkwardly thrusting a skewer amid the glowing embers

title: The Guys Behind ‘Hawk Tuah Girl’ Would Like a Little Credit
description: Right before they filmed the loogie heard around the world, Tim Dickerson and DeArius Marlow were getting ready to go home.

title: Forcing Biden Out Would Have Only One Beneficiary: Trump
description: Joe Biden refuses to drop out of the presidential race even as some liberals, rattled by the incumbent’s frightening debate performance last week, keep pressuring him to do so.

title: Should Biden Quit? Democrats Weigh Potential Rewards and Steep Risks
Audrey Flack, Creator of Vibrant Photorealist Art, Dies at 93
description: Audrey Flack, a pioneer of photorealism who became known for oversize, in-your-face still lifes crowded with color and detail, died on Friday in Southampton, N.Y. She was 93.

title: ‘Seven Samurai’: Masterless Warriors in a Cinematic Masterpiece
description: Few movies have been more influential than “Seven Samurai,” an existential action film directed by Akira Kurosawa that, at longer than three hours, seemingly muscled its way into existence.

title: Some Californians Found Dream Homes Inland. But It Sure Is Hot There.
description: When Farwa Ali and her family wanted to buy a bigger home, Mountain House, Calif., seemed to check all of their boxes.

title: ‘Despicable Me 4’ Review: This Time They’re Superheroes
description: If one wonders how a franchise on its sixth film in under 15 years (counting spinoffs) could still have any good ideas, one solution, apparently, is to simply throw all ideas at the screen. That’s the approach taken in “Despicable Me 4,” the latest, messily passable iteration of the deliriously successful franchise that follows the adventures of the reformed supervillain Gru.

title: Thursday Briefing: What’s at Stake in Britain’s Elections
Rob Stone, Master Marketer of Hip-Hop, Is Dead at 55
description: Rob Stone, who as a founder of the music magazine The Fader and the brand-strategy firm Cornerstone Agency bridged the sounds of the streets and the corporate suites, giving early exposure to rappers like Kanye West and Drake while brokering lucrative endorsements at a time when corporate America was still resistant to hip-hop, died on June 24 in Mount Kisco, N.Y. He was 55.

title: $2.65 Billion Saks-Neiman Marcus Acquisition Will Create a Luxury Retail Giant
description: In a move that would further consolidate the luxury retail market, the parent company of Saks Fifth Avenue has agreed to acquire Neiman Marcus in a $2.65 billion deal, creating the ultimate high-end department store behemoth, the companies announced on Wednesday.

title: Democrats’ Anxiety on Display as Jill Biden Opens Michigan Campaign Office
description: Jill Biden, the first lady, sought to reassure a roomful of Michigan Democrats on Wednesday that her husband was up to the job and that he could still win a second term in the White House despite a rocky debate performance last week. Not all of them were convinced.

title: Raúl Grijalva Is Second House Democrat to Call for Biden to Drop Out
description: Representative Raúl M. Grijalva, a progressive Arizona Democrat, on Wednesday became the second House Democrat to publicly urge President Biden to leave the race, citing the “precarious” state of the president’s campaign.

title: Netflix Co-Founder Becomes One of the Biggest Democratic Donors to Call for Biden to Step Aside
description: Reed Hastings, the Netflix co-founder who in recent years has become one of the biggest donors to the Democratic Party, called on Wednesday for President Biden to relinquish his place atop of the Democratic presidential ticket.

title: French Director Benoît Jacquot Is Charged With Rape
description: The French movie director Benoît Jacquot was charged on Wednesday with the rape of two actresses, Julia Roy and Isild Le Besco, several years ago, according to the Paris prosecutor’s office.

title: America’s Virulent Anti-Vaccine Lies
description: Typically, Americans learn about the clandestine depravities undertaken abroad by their government only decades after the offenses were committed. But last month, one ugly episode was revealed from the still-inflamed recent past: In a report for Reuters, Chris Bing and Joel Schectman documented that, in 2020 and 2021, the Department of Defense conducted an extensive, international disinformation campaign initially intended to discredit Chinese vaccines in the Philippines, a nominal ally, and later among Muslim-majority countries in Central Asia.

title: Biden Insists He Will Stay in the Race
description: President Biden called into his campaign’s all-staff meeting today and unequivocally declared that he was “in this race to the end.” His press secretary also told reporters that Biden was “absolutely not” considering withdrawal.

title: If You Test Positive for Covid, Can You Still Travel?
description: As new coronavirus variants gain traction across the United States, summer travelers are facing a familiar and tiresome question: How will the ever-mutating virus affect travel plans?

title: All Democratic Governors Attend White House Meeting With Biden
description: All of the country’s Democratic governors were in attendance either virtually or in person at a meeting with President Biden on Wednesday night, the White House said, amid the ongoing political fallout from his performance at last Thursday’s debate.

title: Israel Kills a Top Commander of Hezbollah, Which Replies With a Rocket Barrage
description: Israeli forces killed a senior Hezbollah commander on Wednesday in a drone strike in southern Lebanon, prompting the Lebanese militia to retaliate with a heavy rocket barrage across the border.

title: How to Stop Child Marriage? Punish Husbands, Parents and Wedding Guests.
description: The president of the small West African country of Sierra Leone signed a law on Tuesday that banned marriage for children age 18 and younger and would impose steep fines on adult spouses. The move was a victory for activists who had long fought to eradicate the widespread practice.

title: Six Days Shook Biden’s Candidacy. Can He Turn It Around?
description: Good evening. Things are moving fast right now. Tonight, I’ll start by telling you the very latest, and then I’ll explain how six days turned politics upside down. We’re also looking at how Biden is fighting for his candidacy on the air.

title: How to Protect Yourself From Wildfire Smoke
description: Extreme wildfires are becoming more common, more intense and more of a pressing problem for public health. This week, more than 20,000 people in Northern California evacuated their homes as flames destroyed houses and cars.

title: 162 Years Later, a Medal of Honor for Two Civil War Train Raiders
description: The plan was bold, but ultimately doomed.

title: No Corrections: July 3, 2024
description: Errors are corrected during the press run whenever possible, so some errors noted here may not have appeared in all editions.

title: Judge Backs Challenge to F.T.C.’s Noncompete Ban, at Least for Now
description: A federal judge on Wednesday backed an initial legal challenge to the Federal Trade Commission’s ban on noncompete agreements, which is scheduled to take effect in September.

title: How the Pressure Grew for Biden to Drop Out
description: A small but vocal faction of party members urged the president to withdraw from the race or consider doing so in time for a replacement to be chosen.

title: Here Comes the ‘KHive’: Buzz for Kamala Harris Grows After Biden’s Debate Stumble
description: Imagine a presidency that could be, unburdened by what has been.

title: If Biden Drops Out, How Long Do Democrats Have to Pick a Nominee?
description: Editors Note: An earlier version of this article misstated Ohio’s deadline for a candidate to be certified. Ohio legislators passed a bill extending the deadline, and it is no longer before the Democratic convention.

title: How Biden Has Gotten in the Way of Fighting Starvation in Gaza
description: In responding to the war in Gaza for more than eight months, President Biden has often seemed weak — upset over the humanitarian toll but not acting firmly to reduce it.

title: Menendez Defense Rests Without Senator Testifying
description: After calling just four witnesses, lawyers for Senator Robert Menendez of New Jersey rested their case late Wednesday afternoon in Manhattan federal court, setting the stage for jurors to begin deliberations in his international bribery conspiracy trial early next week.

title: Lightning Is Blamed for Deadly New Mexico Fire
description: Lightning sparked the larger of the two wildfires that have scorched southern New Mexico, leaving at least two people dead, destroying 1,400 structures and ravaging more than 25,000 acres, the authorities said on Wednesday.

title: Hurricane Beryl Batters Jamaica as 2 Other Islands Lie in Ruin
description: Jamaica was still being hammered by strong winds and heavy rain early Thursday as Hurricane Beryl passed its southern coast, having claimed at least one life on the island. The powerful storm, which devastated communities in the eastern Caribbean earlier in the week, was headed next to the Cayman Islands.

title: Ex-Engineer Charged With Obstructing Inquiry Into Military Crash That Killed 16
description: A former U.S. Air Force engineer has been charged with making false statements and obstructing justice during a federal criminal investigation into a 2017 military plane crash that killed 16 people, the Justice Department said Wednesday.

title: Resembles a Tractor
description: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues

title: Biden Tells Governors That He Is Staying in the Race
description: President Biden told a group of Democratic governors on Wednesday that he was staying in the 2024 campaign, as the group peppered the president with questions about the path forward after Mr. Biden’s disastrous debate performance last week.

title: After Island Loses Its Only Hospital, Grenada Scrambles for an Alternative
description: Officials in Grenada were scrambling on Wednesday to set up a field hospital after Hurricane Beryl ravaged nearly all the buildings on the nation’s island of Carriacou, including its lone hospital.

title: Corrections: July 4, 2024
description: An article on Wednesday about Leonard Peltier, a Native American activist who supporters say was unfairly convicted of killing two federal agents nearly 50 years ago, misstated the given name of the deputy director of research at Amnesty International USA. He is Justin Mazzola, not James.

title: Quotation of the Day: Odd Contest: Go Slow, Save Whales, Win a Prize
description: “It’s like drivers slowing down in a school zone in the presence of schoolchildren.”

title: Is Xenophobia on Chinese Social Media Teaching Real-World Hate?
description: The video posted last year on Chinese social media showed more than 100 Japanese children, supposedly at an elementary school in Shanghai, gathered in their schoolyard. Chinese subtitles quoted two students leading the group as screaming: “Shanghai is ours. Soon the whole China will be ours, too.”

title: What Makes the U.K. Exit Poll So Trusted
description: Follow our live updates on the U.K. election.

title: As Britain Votes, Change Is in the Air. Optimism, Not So Much.
description: Follow our live updates on the U.K. election.

title: Iranians’ Demand for Their Leaders: Fix the Economy
description: In the working-class neighborhood of Tehran surrounding Imam Hussein Square, the side streets and alleys are lined with secondhand stores and small repair shops for refurbishing all manner of household goods. But with little to do, most shopkeepers idle in front of their stores.

title: Hezbollah Fired 200 Rockets at Israel. Here’s What to Know About the Escalating Tensions.
description: For months, concerns have grown that the war in Gaza might ignite a second conflict between Israel and Hezbollah, the well-armed militia that is loosely allied with Hamas and based just across Israel’s northern border with Lebanon.

title: Thursday Briefing
description: Britain votes today after a campaign that featured the same ingredients as other elections across Europe and the Americas: frustrated voters eager to reject the status quo, a deeply discredited government and a dash of populism.

title: India’s Cable News Predicted a Big Modi Win. How Did They Get It So Wrong?
description: Through the months of India’s sprawling national election season, the country’s hundreds of cable news outlets all seemed to be trying to outdo each other: They predicted that Prime Minister Narendra Modi would win, and win big.

title: Boil-Water Advisory Is Lifted in Washington and Northern Virginia
description: The authorities in Washington and Arlington, Va., on Wednesday advised all 920,000 residents to boil their drinking water after they discovered that algae blooms in the Potomac River had raised pollution levels in a reservoir.

title: Loving America Means Expecting More From It
description: Patriotism did not bring my grandfather to the Army recruiter’s office in 1956. Poverty did. A youth spent picking cotton and working odd jobs to help feed his family meant that he was a good way from graduating from high school as his 18th birthday approached. He wanted a better life for himself and saw the Army as a way to make it happen.

title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.

title: New York Moves to Clean Up Times Square After a Spate of Crimes
description: A man attacked with a machete. A young woman killed after the police said a 22-year-old woman stabbed her in an unprovoked attack near the Port Authority bus terminal. A carpenter waiting for a co-worker in the bus station stabbed nine times as he sat and read.

title: Things to Take to College That You Can’t Buy at Target
description: Extra-long sheets. Shower shoes. The wall hooks and putty that hold things up but don’t leave marks.

title: Hot Dog Eating Contest Crowns Patrick Bertoletti as New Men’s Champion
description: It was the Fourth of July in New York City, and for some, that meant only one thing. No, not fireworks, sweaty subway rides and family cookouts. It was time for the Nathan’s Famous Hot Dog Eating Contest in Coney Island.

title: Why a New Conservative Brain Trust Is Resettling Across America
description: The Claremont Institute has been located in Southern California since its founding in the late 1970s. From its perch in the foothills of the San Gabriel Mountains, it has become a leading intellectual center of the pro-Trump right.

title: The Booty-Shaking Anthem That Still Endures, 25 Years Later
description: Twenty-five hot summers ago, Juvenile threw out a command and booties everywhere have never been the same. That’s when “Back That Azz Up,” the second single from the New Orleans rapper’s album “400 Degreez,” was released and almost instantly became the national anthem of twerking — before the word even entered the American vocabulary.

title: Beach Reads That Stand Up to Sand, Salt and SPF
description: There was a time not long ago when you could stroll down a beach and get ideas for your next book: Sunbathers held hardcovers in their hands; swimmers left paperbacks facedown on towels. The shoreline was an open-air bookstore window, a browsing bonanza that led straight to borrowing or buying your next read. Of course you’d have to pick up an ice cream cone on this expedition, and maybe a pound of fudge.

title: Joy Williams Grudgingly Revises, Word by Word
description: What books are on your night stand?

title: Europe Seeks to Solve the ‘Patriot Puzzle’ in Ukraine
description: A European plan to give Ukraine another Patriot air defense system to protect its battered cities from Russian airstrikes is coming together, piece by piece.

title: Cindy Crawford Is Here to Stay
description: When Cindy Crawford walked into a lounge in the Santa Monica Proper Hotel on a morning in early June, her vibe was immediate: comfortable, professional, direct. No artifice. No entourage. Just her longtime publicist Annett Wolf, who made a brief introduction and disappeared, leaving Ms. Crawford at the head of a table set with a display of the products from her Meaningful Beauty line of skin and hair care, a $400 million brand she introduced 20 years ago.

title: Beach Reads With Depth
description: A summer day at the beach is a perfect time to read a book, but does the book need to be light and fluffy? Our critic Alexandra Jacobs argues that a beach day is the perfect time to slow down and dig into a book with some depth. She brings us three books, all featuring the ocean, that show the sea as more than just fun and froth.

title: The Dazzling Artistry of Hiroshige’s ‘100 Famous Views of Edo’
description: If you want to understand the visual language of Instagram, cinema, Tintin comics, modern poster design, or van Gogh, the quickest thing to do would be to ride out to the Brooklyn Museum, where, for the first time in 24 years, you can see every one of Utagawa Hiroshige’s “100 Famous Views of Edo” (the city now known as Tokyo).

title: 6 Podcasts About the Past That Resonate
description: Over the past few years, debates have been waged over how American history should be taught in schools, particularly subjects like slavery and racism. Covering everything from ancient civilizations to 20th-century politics, these six shows deliver incisive and engaging lessons that will resonate no matter how much you learned (or paid attention) in history class.

title: Gettysburg’s Lost Cause Problem
description: Amid a sea of stone plaques and obelisks at Gettysburg National Military Park in Pennsylvania sits a modest monument to the First Minnesota Infantry Regiment. Inscribed on its side is one of the most astonishing accounts of heroism in American history.

title: A Hacker Stole OpenAI Secrets, Raising Fears That China Could, Too
description: Early last year, a hacker gained access to the internal messaging systems of OpenAI, the maker of ChatGPT, and stole details about the design of the company’s A.I. technologies.

title: Apartments Could Be the Next Real Estate Business to Struggle
description: It might seem like a great time to own apartment buildings.

title: On Small Islands Off Canada’s Coast, a Big Shift in Power
description: The Raven, the story goes, alighted on the beach and heard sounds coming from a giant clamshell. He found creatures cowering inside but, ever the trickster, he cajoled them out into the world. Liberated, they became the first people of the islands of Haida Gwaii.

title: Why the Flag Looks Like That. And Like That. And Like That.
description: When the news broke that an upside-down American flag, a protest symbol carried by the Jan. 6 rioters, had flown above the home of a Supreme Court justice, some saw it as a sign of how badly the court had been corrupted. Others saw it as a sign of how badly the news media had been corrupted. For me, the unfurling scandal was a testament to the enduring expressive power of flags.

title: ‘MaXXXine’ Review: Fame Monster
description: A psychosexual thriller imagined in blood red and cocaine white, “MaXXXine,” the third installment in Ti West’s nostalgia-soaked slasher saga, is part grungy homage to 1980s Hollywood and part sleazy feminist manifesto. Darker, moodier and altogether nastier than its predecessors — “X” (2022) and, later that same year, “Pearl” — this hyperconfident feature is also funny, occasionally wistful and deeply empathetic toward its damaged, driven heroine.

title: Piñatas That Provide Awe Instead of Candy
description: The piñata, because it’s made out of humble paper and designed to be obliterated, is not always thought of as art. The Los Angeles-based artist Roberto Benavidez has worked to change that.

title: Do You Live in a Swing State and Don’t Plan on Voting?
description: The outcome of the 2024 presidential election is likely to come down to thin margins in a handful of swing states: Arizona, Georgia, Michigan, Nevada, Pennsylvania and Wisconsin.

title: Why I Won’t Vote
description: Abstinence is having what I believe is called a moment. Everywhere a vast literature of self-denial proclaims the benefits of not drinking, not eating carbohydrates, not having sex, not watering one’s lawn. Practically the only thing from which the American people are not serially asked to refrain happens to be the one vice that I have managed to renounce, in my case with very little difficulty. I mean, of course, voting.

title: This Service Cat Has a Big Job: The Apocalypse
description: How did a cat named Schnitzel win the starring role of Frodo in “A Quiet Place: Day One”? He impressed the director Michael Sarnoski with his nonchalant confidence, rugged looks and intelligent face.

title: 36 Hours in Boston
description: Soak up history, relax in beer gardens that pop open like tulips in summer, and make a pilgrimage to Fenway Park.

title: A Masterpiece of Fiction Inspires the Urge to Submerge in a Gallery Crawl
description: “Oh, how bonny and lush were the banks of the Lucinda River!”

title: Homes for Sale in Connecticut and New York
description: A three-bedroom, two-and-a-half-bath, 3,093-square-foot midcentury modern home overlooking the Saugatuck River, with a stone entryway and original woodwork, cathedral ceilings, a renovated open kitchen with white cabinetry and a large island, a wood-burning fireplace with brass inlays, a primary suite with an office and a soaking tub, sliders to a deck, a walkout lower level with a family room and two bedrooms, a gym, a mudroom, a two-car garage and a spacious deck, on two acres. Kristi Law, 917-576-6638; Jim Gricar, 917-592-4425. William Pitt Sotheby’s International; williampitt.com

title: Like a Firing Squad, but for Romantic Rejection
description: The rubber balloon has worn many hats since it was invented 200 years ago. It has been used to spruce up birthday parties and political rallies, operate flying machines and open arteries. The fictional killer clown Pennywise used one to lure in his child victims; some expectant parents deploy them to reveal their unborn child’s sex.

title: A Divided America Agrees: We Deserve Better Than This
description: The latest national poll from The New York Times and Siena College shows former President Donald J. Trump leading President Biden by nine percentage points among registered voters — a pretty big shift in his direction in the week since the presidential debate.

title: Legal Conservatives’ Long Game: Amp Up Presidential Power but Kneecap Federal Agencies
description: The Supreme Court seemed to take two views of executive power this term, saying presidents should have immunity to free them from constraints while also scaling back the ability of the executive branch to impose regulations.

title: Who Should Lead the Democratic Ticket? Six Columnists Weigh In.
description: With President Biden’s candidacy in question, we asked six New York Times Opinion columnists: Who would you like to see as the Democratic nominee? Read their answers below. Or listen here:

title: Fight Over Seabed Agency Leadership Turns Nasty
description: Allegations of possible payments to help secure votes. Claims of abuse of agency funds by top diplomats. A possible job offer to entice a candidate to withdraw from a race.

title: Clothes of the Rich, Famous and Fabulous
description: Couture week in Paris is a reminder that the clothes many people consider to be the most splendid in the world are accessible to only a select few with means and connections. That doesn’t mean the shows are not fun to see.

title: Your Religious Values Are Not American Values
description: Whenever a politician cites “Judeo-Christian values,” I find it’s generally followed by something unsettling.

title: Homes for Sale in Manhattan and Brooklyn
description: A one-bedroom, one-bath, roughly 700-square-foot apartment with a small windowed kitchen, a windowed marble bathroom, gold-leaf ceilings, PTAC heating and air-conditioning, and ample closets, on the 15th floor of a 17-story prewar doorman building with a live-in super, a waiting list for basement storage cages and a bike room. Epo I. Manning and Florence Danforth-Meyer, Sotheby’s International Realty, 917-359-4903; sothebysrealty.com

title: From an R.V. to a Condo Near Washington: Which Was Better for Their Growing Family?
description: After spending two years on the road and having a baby, a young couple decided to put down roots just south of the nation’s capital. Here’s what they found.

title: Trump Stays Quiet (Relatively), Hoping Biden Stays in the Race
description: Amid the flurry of Democrats’ questioning whether President Biden should or will remain his party’s presidential nominee, former President Donald J. Trump has stayed unusually quiet on the issue publicly.

title: How a Weekend of Media and Memes Shaped Six Voters’ Thoughts About the Debate
description: We asked six voters around the country to send us all the media they saw or heard after the debate. Here is what we learned.

title: The Brokes Play the Strokes for an Adoring New York Crowd
description: More than two decades after the Strokes led an indie rock renaissance in New York City, a Strokes cover band called the Brokes played a sold-out show at Arlene’s Grocery, a small venue on the Lower East Side.

title: No Poll Can Tell Biden What He Needs to Hear
description: “Will this be the thing that causes his voters to abandon him? How much will this hurt his numbers?” are questions that I, as a pollster, have been asked a lot over the past eight years. And the answers are almost always the same: You know, as crazy as it may seem, any one event might not move numbers very much.

title: Europe Tells China’s Carmakers: Get Ready to Pay Tariffs
description: The European Union took the next step on Thursday toward collecting new tariffs on Chinese electric cars, telling automakers to obtain guarantees from banks that they would be able to pay the taxes set to be made final in October.

title: The Connections Companion No. 390, July 5, 2024
description: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.

title: Wordle Review No. 1,112, July 5, 2024
description: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

title: Biden’s Slipping Support
description: A major Times poll has found that voters’ doubts about President Biden deepened after his poor performance in the first debate, with Donald J. Trump taking by far his biggest lead of the campaign.

title: Netflix Show Earns Its Saudi Creator Plaudits, and a Prison Sentence
description: From the outside, the past few years looked like the peak of Abdulaziz Almuzaini’s career.

title: Biden in Crisis
description: The political climate for President Biden is worse this morning than it was just a few days ago.

title: ‘Kill’ Review: The Title Says It All. Over and Over Again.
description: We are almost halfway through the Indian action extravaganza “Kill” before the title card slams onscreen, by which point its simple imperative — and the film’s entire raison d’être — has been obeyed so many times it’s essentially redundant. Much like the movie’s English subtitles: The dialogue might be in Hindi, but the language of blood and bones is universal.

title: ‘The Imaginary’ Review: Off to Another World
description: Imagination is the abstract space that can most potently symbolize childlike joy and wonder — at least, according to the opening scene of “The Imaginary,” with its sweeping fantastical vistas sprouting from the inside of a child’s mind. In truth, our imaginations and the friends we make along the way are, within this poignant and inventive animated film directed by Yoshiyuki Momose, arenas where we reckon with emotional turmoil and the loss of innocence.

title: ‘Mother, Couch’ Review: The Family That Stays Together
description: In a furniture store devoid of customers, an elderly matriarch, referred to only as “Mother” and played by Ellen Burstyn, has settled on a couch. That is, she’s really settled on a couch. She’s sitting on it and refusing to budge. She promises that if anyone tries to move or carry her off the couch, she will struggle to the extent that, “I will fall and hit my head so hard it will burst.”

title: U.S. and Israel Voice New Optimism About Cease-Fire as Gaza Talks Resume
description: American and Israeli officials on Thursday expressed renewed optimism over a cease-fire deal in the Gaza Strip, after Hamas revised its position and Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel then told President Biden that he was sending a new delegation of negotiators to the stalled talks.

title: First Black African-Born Member of German Parliament Won’t Seek Re-election
description: Germany’s first Black African-born member of Parliament said this week that he would not seek office again in next year’s general elections. Although he played down racism as a factor, he made the announcement in the wake of a slew of hate mail, death threats he said he has received, as well as multiple violent attacks on his office.

title: This English Naval City Is a Bellwether Seat. How Do Voters Feel?
description: Voters streamed into a polling station in Portsmouth, a city nestled along England’s southern coast that is known for its naval base and historic dockyard, on Thursday morning as ballot workers greeted them warmly.

title: A New Principal Takes Her Bow at American Ballet Theater
