description: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.

title: Is One Third of Venezuela’s Population About to Flee?
description: For years, Venezuelans have been living through one of the most severe economic collapses in modern history — one that has caused millions to flee the country. But this weekend, an election is offering many a real hope for change.

title: Arson Disrupts Olympics Travel, and Obama Endorses Harris
description: On Today’s Episode:

title: Here are the train lines affected by the attacks.
description: The coordinated arson attacks on the French railway system that disrupted train service across northern France and beyond on Friday morning were expected to upend travel plans for about 800,000 customers, the national railway company said.

title: The New Race
description: With 101 days until Election Day, I want to use today’s newsletter to frame the coming campaign. No doubt, more surprises lie ahead. But there is now enough stability — and enough polling since President Biden’s exit — to make three points about the race.

title: Precautions Failed to Halt Rail Sabotage
description: The coordinated rail attacks that disrupted train travel in France on three high-speed lines Friday morning occurred despite intensive security precautions put into effect leading to the Olympics, which officially begin Friday night.

title: Arson Attacks on French Rail Leave People Stranded
description: The usual rhythm of arrivals and departures at Paris’s train stations was replaced by a tense atmosphere of uncertainty on Friday. Hundreds of stranded passengers crowded the concourses, sorting out their plans after several arson attacks disrupted the rail system in France.

title: Behind the Democrats’ Fight Over Lina Khan’s Future
description: News that Reid Hoffman, the billionaire LinkedIn co-founder and major Democratic donor, wants Vice President Kamala Harris, if she wins in November, to replace Lina Khan as chair of the F.T.C. provoked outrage on the left. Senator Bernie Sanders, independent of Vermont, called it “unacceptable,” and Tim Wu, the Columbia Law School professor and former Biden antitrust official, demanded that the Harris campaign return Hoffman’s donations.

title: Here’s How The New York Times Is Bringing You the Olympics
description: Whether you are one of the more than 10,000 elite athletes competing in the 2024 Paris Summer Olympics or an armchair admirer, it is go time.

title: What We Know About the Attacks on France’s Rail Network
description: As Paris lit up for the Olympics opening ceremony on Friday night, railway workers were frantically repairing parts of the country’s high-speed rail network that had been set alight in a set of coordinated arson attacks.

title: Fed’s Preferred Inflation Measure Cooled Overall in June
description: The Federal Reserve’s preferred inflation measure continued to gradually cool overall in June even as a “core” inflation measure held steady, likely enough evidence of progress to keep the central bank on track for a rate cut later this year but not enough to stoke speculation that it might reduce rates at its meeting next week.

title: Chase to Bar Customers From Using Credit Cards for ‘Pay Later’ Loans
description: JPMorgan Chase, the nation’s largest credit card issuer, will bar customers from using its credit cards to repay increasingly popular “buy now, pay later” installment loans.

title: Summer Reading Contest, Week 8: What Got Your Attention in The Times This Week?
description: Welcome to the eighth week of our 15th Annual Summer Reading Contest.

title: 104 Shows. $260 Million. After 10 Years, Billy Joel Closes a Chapter.
description: There’s a pause before Billy Joel steps onstage each night when he makes the subtle transition from low-key Everyman to world-renowned Piano Man. It’s just a few minutes of “not talking to anybody, not seeing anybody,” he said, mimicking waving off potential distractions. He makes sure he can hit his high notes. Then the roar of the crowd does the rest.

title: He Wrote a Story About Joy, Then Built a Tiny World to Match
description: This story begins, as many of the best tales do, with the arrival of a dog.

title: A New Batman Is Less a Dark Knight Than a ‘Weird and Creepy’ One
description: The story of Batman has been told in comic books and onscreen many times. But if there’s one person who should get the chance to tell it again, it is Bruce Timm.

title: 130 Years After Sinking, Ship is Found on the Bottom of Lake Michigan
description: Early on Sept. 30, 1893, the Margaret A. Muir schooner, carrying cargo of bulk salt, cleared the narrow Straits of Mackinac on its way down Lake Michigan toward Chicago’s port. As the crew rounded Michigan and steered south, the ship encountered relentless 50-mile-an-hour winds.

title: Spaceman, Senator, V.P. Pick? Kamala Harris Sizes Up Mark Kelly.
description: The rugged border lands around Douglas, Ariz., dip through precipitous canyons and shoot skyward on rocky mountain walls, impossible terrain for a 30-foot steel bollard wall but not for the cartels smuggling people and contraband from Mexico.

title: New York Will Allow Beth Israel Hospital to Close
description: The New York State Department of Health has agreed to allow a major hospital in Manhattan to close, which would leave many downtown residents farther away from emergency medical care.

title: Automakers Sold Driver Data for Pennies, Senators Say
description: If you drive a car made by General Motors and it has an internet connection, your car’s movements and exact location are being collected and shared anonymously with a data broker.

title: Saying Goodbye to the Messy, Murderous World of ‘Elite’
description: Shooting the eighth and final season of Netflix’s teen crime drama “Elite” last November, crew members yelled “silencio” so often it could have been mistaken for a chant.

title: With Kamala Harris, U.S. Free Trade Skepticism May Continue
description: In a 2019 presidential debate, Kamala Harris insisted, “I am not a protectionist Democrat.”

title: As Trump Looms, Blinken Aims to Reassure Allies on U.S. Commitment to Asia
description: For three and a half years, President Biden and his aides have insisted that the United States is a Pacific power, and that its allies and partners in the region need not worry about Washington’s commitments.

title: Top Real Estate Agent Faces Another Claim of Sexual Assault
description: An actress and comedian says she was drugged and sexually assaulted by Oren Alexander, a top luxury real estate agent who is facing a string of accusations that he and two of his brothers sexually assaulted women — allegations that had been whispered throughout the high-end real estate industry for years.

title: Heirs of Jews Who Fled the Nazis Return Art to Heirs Whose Family Could Not
description: “Seated Nude Woman,” a drawing by the Austrian Expressionist Egon Schiele, was returned on Friday to the heirs of Fritz Grünbaum, a Jewish art collector and Viennese cabaret performer who was killed by the Nazis during the Holocaust.

title: Scandal Hits U.K.’s ‘Strictly Come Dancing,’ the Original ‘Dancing With the Stars’
description: For almost two decades, viewers in Britain have watched celebrities jive, waltz and cha-cha-cha on “Strictly Come Dancing,” a BBC reality television show that inspired the international “Dancing With the Stars” franchise.

title: Billy Joel at the Garden: Scenes From a Celebration
description: Billy Joel performed the final show of his 10-year residency at Madison Square Garden on Thursday night, his 150th performance at the venue overall and the most for any performer there. The Times was on hand to capture the moments leading up to the concert, which amounted to a victory lap.

title: Cherries for Black Forest Cake, Tomatoes for Gazpacho, Swordfish for Piccata
description: Good morning. I had smoked chicken wings on the menu for dinner, a beautiful salad of sliced, salted tomatoes with a fist of burrata and some drizzled balsamic vinegar, a Black Forest sheet cake (above) for dessert. That seemed enough — the cake, especially, with its blanket of whipped cream and studdings of cherry.

title: Ask NYT Climate
description: Your climate change and environment questions answered by Times journalists and experts.

title: U.K. Drops Opposition to International Criminal Court Warrant for Netanyahu
description: Britain on Friday confirmed it was dropping plans to challenge the pursuit of an international warrant against Israel’s prime minister, Benjamin Netanyahu, in the International Criminal Court, underscoring a shift in foreign policy under the country’s new prime minister, Keir Starmer.

title: Town Famous for Royal and Hollywood Guests Is Ravaged by Wildfires
description: Queen Elizabeth II vacationed there, as did her parents before her. Hollywood’s royalty were regular visitors, too. Marilyn Monroe filmed scenes for “River of No Return” there, and “The Emperor Waltz” brought Bing Crosby and Joan Fontaine to its golf courses and tennis courts. The mountains of Jasper, Alberta, have also stood in for peaks around the world in other movies.

title: After Urging Israel to End War, Trump Says He Has ‘Good Relationship’ With Netanyahu
description: Former President Donald J. Trump, who has for months urged Israel to end the war in Gaza as quickly as possible, insisted that he and Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel were on good terms after the two met on Friday in Palm Beach, Fla.

Tesla on Tuesday reported a 45 percent decline in profit in the second quarter of 2024. The drop from the same period a year ago was the latest example of the auto maker’s weak sales of electric vehicles and a sign that its investments in emerging technology could take many years to pay off.

title: Battling Inflation, Russia Raises Key Interest Rate to 18 Percent
description: Russia’s central bank raised its key interest rate to 18 percent on Friday, the highest level in more than two years, in a sign of mounting concern in Moscow that the country’s wartime economy risked producing runaway inflation.

title: Saboteurs Targeted a Rail Network So Vast That It’s Impossible to Fully Secure
description: France took virtually every precaution to make sure that its capital would be secure when all eyes were on the city for the opening ceremony of the Paris Olympics.

title: In JD Vance Country, an Addiction Scourge That Won’t Go Away
description: Sitting in a KFC restaurant in the former coal-mining town of Pomeroy, Ohio, a few hours before JD Vance addressed the Republican National Convention, Curtis Ramsey, 18, recalled the first time he heard the Ohio senator’s name.

title: Prominent Short Seller Made Millions Off Bait-and-Switch Scheme, U.S. Says
description: Federal prosecutors and securities regulators filed criminal and civil fraud charges against a well-known investor who frequently appeared on cable TV business shows to discuss his often bearish views on stocks, the authorities said on Friday.

title: Roland Dumas Dies at 101; French Foreign Minister Tainted by Scandal
description: Roland Dumas, a former French foreign minister, agile political fixer and star defense lawyer whose taste for living large proved his undoing, died on July 3 in Paris. He was 101.

title: Five International Movies to Stream Now
description: Stream it on Ovid.

title: For Epidemics to Cross Oceans, Viruses on Ships Had to Beat the Odds
description: On Dec. 22, 1874, the H.M.S. Dido arrived in Fiji from Sydney, Australia, carrying about 200 people and an invisible payload. A king of Fiji and his son, who were on the ship, were infected with measles. When they debarked, they started an epidemic that killed 20,000 people in Fiji — up to one-fourth of the population — who had no immunity to the disease.

title: Can Fees on Polluting Cars Clean the Air? London Has New Evidence.
description: When pollution meets politics, efforts to clean up the air in the world’s big cities can bring risks as well as wins. London and New York got a taste of it this week.

title: The Truth About Shark Attacks
description: Find out just how dangerous your beach day really is.

title: Book Club: Let’s Talk About ‘The Talented Mr. Ripley’
description: Patricia Highsmith’s 1955 thriller “The Talented Mr. Ripley” follows a young, down-on-his-luck scammer, Tom Ripley, who is looking to reverse his fortunes. When he receives a job offer to go to Italy and retrieve Dickie Greenleaf, a rich socialite on an endless holiday, Tom finds the perfect opportunity to work his way into the upper crust. But as he becomes more and more obsessed with Dickie and Dickie’s life, the breezy getaway turns into something much more sinister, sending them down a dangerous path.

title: Lady Gaga Opens With an Ode to French Cabaret
description: Lady Gaga was pure panache in the opening production number of the opening ceremony: a tribute to cabaret with “Mon Truc en Plumes” (“My Thing With Feathers”), a cabaret standard originally performed by Zizi Jeanmaire. Flaunting a pink feathered pom-pop, and surrounded by dancers with plenty more of them, she flaunted her tangy voice and some strutting moves, and also played piano.

title: With a No-Fail Mission, the Secret Service Strains to Make Do
description: Over the years, whenever the United States Secret Service’s lack of resources has been an issue, agents invoke a tongue-in-cheek motto: We do more with less.

title: Fast-Moving Wildfires Burn Canada’s Jasper National Park
description: Devastating wildfires have forced thousands of residents and tourists to evacuate Jasper, Canada.

title: Two Women Killed in Upper East Side Murder-Suicide
description: Two women were shot to death in a murder-suicide on the Upper East Side of Manhattan on Friday morning, according to the police.

title: Transcript: Ezra Klein Interviews Ben Wikler
description: Every Tuesday and Friday, Ezra Klein invites you into a conversation about something that matters, like today’s episode with Ben Wikler. Listen wherever you get your podcasts.

title: Anger Lingers Over Positive Doping Tests for Chinese Swimmers
description: The days before the Olympic swimming competition are often a chance for the world’s best swimmers to share their hopes and expectations.

title: Rail Sabotage Blights an Olympic Moment for France
description: Before dawn on the day of the opening ceremony of the Paris Olympics, arsonists on Friday sabotaged three critical high-speed rail lines, stranding thousands of travelers, heightening security fears and blighting what President Emmanuel Macron hoped to be a moment of national glory.

title: California Wildfire Races Through a Forest Community, in a Haunting Reminder
description: Ryan Kendall’s crew of firefighters arrived too late to save the house on Dear Abby Road.

title: Museum of Natural History Says It Is Repatriating 124 Human Remains
description: The American Museum of Natural History said it was making progress on returning the human remains of nearly 2,200 Native Americans and thousands of tribal funerary objects, which became a top priority earlier this year in the wake of new federal regulations.

title: What was with that heavy metal band? That was Gojira.
description: Gojira, a leading French heavy metal band, became the first hard rock act to perform in an Olympic Games opening ceremony when it did a metal version of “Ah! Ça Ira,” a song that was popular during the French Revolution. The band had reworked the song in collaboration with Victor le Masne, and performed with the opera singer Marina Viotti.

title: Campaign Advice for Kamala Harris
description: To the Editor:

title: Kamala Harris Needs a 3 P.M. Agenda
description: Vice President Kamala Harris has what she used to call a 3 a.m. agenda. To be an effective president, she’ll need to add a 3 p.m. agenda.

title: LeBron James and Coco Gauff are the U.S. Flag Bearers
description: The N.B.A. star LeBron James of the Los Angeles Lakers and the tennis star Coco Gauff were chosen by their peers to be flag bearers for the United States on Friday night at the Paris Olympics’ opening ceremony, which will be held in boats floating along the Seine

title: Jerry Miller, 81, Lauded Guitarist With the ’60s Band Moby Grape, Dies
description: Jerry Miller, an acclaimed guitarist who emerged from the Pacific Northwest club circuit to make his mark on San Francisco’s psychedelic rock scene in the 1960s as a founding member of the lauded, if star-crossed, band Moby Grape, died on Sunday at his home in Tacoma, Wash. He was 81.

title: A Canadian Wildfire Grew So Intense It Made Its Own Weather
description: Officials said on Thursday they feared as much as half the town of Jasper, Alberta, had been destroyed by wildfires so intense they generated their own weather.

title: NASA Aims to Restore Space Station Traffic After SpaceX and Boeing Problems
description: NASA officials on Friday said they expected congestion at the International Space Station in the coming month, following a couple of weeks in which it seemed that the agency’s ability to transport astronauts to and from orbit was stuck in a holding pattern.

title: My Partner Told Me About His Fights With His Ex. I Think I’m on Her Side.
description: My partner and I each had several significant relationships before we met. We’re both in therapy and have learned a lot from that, so we’re very comfortable processing past relationships together. One of my partner’s past relationships soured quickly, which led to years of resentment and frustration before it ended. When he processes past arguments with his ex, he sometimes says she ‘‘picked a fight,’’ but when he tells the story, I quietly find that I’m often on her side. I find it odd that he, with all his otherwise tremendous self-awareness, cannot move past what to me feels like a somewhat skewed take on someone else’s valid frustrations.

title: The Obamas Called Kamala Harris. Cameras Rolled. Hokeyness Ensued.
description: Kamala Harris’s dizzying rollout as a presidential candidate somehow pulled off the rare feat of looking organic and organized, fun but without cringe-inducing artifice. Vibes shifted, memes spread, coconuts fell.

title: Vance Calls ‘Cat Ladies’ Remark ‘Sarcasm’ but Amplifies Birthrate Argument
description: Senator JD Vance of Ohio, former President Donald J. Trump’s running mate, on Friday dug in on his past remarks lamenting that the United States was being run by Democrats without children, arguing that their party had become “very anti-child in their messaging and their public policy.”

title: Celebrities Support Plan to Reopen Upper West Side Movie Theater
description: After almost two decades of failed attempts to reopen, a landmark Upper West Side movie theater may be resurrected with a plan from a potential new buyer and celebrity support.

title: Flashback: Your Weekly History Quiz, July 27, 2024
description: Can you sort 8 historical events?

title: Amid Deadly Listeria Outbreak, Boar’s Head Recalls Some Deli Meats
description: Amid an outbreak of listeria that has killed two people in the United States and sickened around three dozen others, Boar’s Head Products announced on Friday that it would recall more than 200,000 pounds of deli meat, including all liverwurst products currently available on the market.

title: The Best of Late Night This Week
description: The head-spinning pace of U.S. political news continues to give the hosts plenty to talk about.

title: Justice Dept. Settles Lawsuit With Former F.B.I. Officials Targeted by Trump
description: The Justice Department settled a lawsuit on Friday with two former F.B.I. officials who had accused the Trump administration of violating their privacy by sharing their texts disparaging former President Donald J. Trump with the news media, according to court documents.

title: When the Game Does Not End at the Final Whistle
description: Somewhere amid the controversy and the chaos, there is the germ of a paradox. Every philosophical quandary requires a scenario, and this is a good one: On Wednesday, the opening day of the men’s soccer tournament at the Paris Olympics, Cristian Medina scored a late — 106th-minute late — equalizer to help Argentina salvage a point against Morocco.

title: How the U.S. Captured One of Mexico’s Biggest Drug Lords
description: It sounded like a story ripped from a narco thriller: One of the biggest drug lords in Mexico was lured onto an airplane, flown across the border and presented to American federal agents by the son of his former partner in crime.

title: Celine Dion Closes Opening Ceremony With Triumphant Return to Stage
description: The stakes could not have been higher for Celine Dion’s first public performance since 2020. After canceling tour dates, in 2022 she announced that she was suffering from a rare neurological disorder known as stiff person syndrome, which causes muscle spasms, including constrictions of her vocal cords. “I Am: Celine Dion,” the documentary released this year, showed her struggling to sing at a recording session.

title: Surfing Teahupo’o’s ‘Wall of Skulls’
description: For the second time in history, surfing is going to be an Olympic sport. Instead of the coast of France, surfers will travel to Teahupo’o, home to some of the world’s most dangerous waves.

title: Warner Bros. Discovery Sues N.B.A. Over Rights Deal
description: Warner Bros. Discovery sued the National Basketball Association on Friday in an attempt to force the league to accept its offer to match Amazon’s bid to broadcast games.

title: Though Critical on Gaza, Trump Cites Good Relations With Netanyahu
description: Former President Donald J. Trump, who for months has urged Israel to end the war in the Gaza Strip as quickly as possible, said that he and Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel remained on good terms after the two met on Friday, and that he would be a stronger ally of Israel than Vice President Kamala Harris.

title: New York to Replace Student MetroCards With Less Restrictive OMNY Cards
description: New York City students will have expanded access to the transit system beginning this coming school year, city officials announced on Thursday.

title: N.C.A.A. Settlement Agreement Reveals How Colleges Would Pay Athletes
description: The N.C.A.A. and the richest college athletic conferences joined with plaintiffs’ lawyers on Friday to enter a $2.8 billion settlement agreement of their class-action antitrust lawsuit. The filing outlines in some detail how schools would be allowed for the first time to pay college athletes directly.

title: The Paris Olympics Opened in Spectacular Style
description: Nearly 7,000 athletes from 206 delegations were ferried down the Seine today in an extravagant and star-studded opening ceremony to kick off the Olympic Games in Paris. As the rain poured, hundreds of thousands of spectators cheered from the river’s banks. And Celine Dion closed out the night with a triumphant return to the stage.

title: Clear Encampments? Mind Your Own Business, Los Angeles Tells Newsom.
description: Gov. Gavin Newsom appeared this week wearing work gloves and Ray-Ban sunglasses as he hauled a garbage bag from under a freeway overpass in California. His message was obvious: He wanted state and local officials to clear out homeless encampments, just as he was doing, and he had signed an executive order to spur them into action.

title: A Weapons Scanner Arrives in the Subway. Adams Says It Isn’t Optional.
description: Mayor Eric Adams announced the start of a contentious new plan to put a gun-detecting scanner in the subway on Friday and warned that New Yorkers who refused to be scanned would be kicked out of the system.

title: Silent No More, Harris Seeks Her Own Voice Without Breaking With Biden
description: After meeting with Israel’s prime minister this week, Vice President Kamala Harris said she “will not be silent.” She was referring to her concerns about Palestinian suffering in the Gaza war, but in a way it was a larger declaration of independence.

title: Gail Lumet Buckley, Chronicler of Black Family History, Dies at 86
description: Gail Lumet Buckley, who rather than follow her mother, Lena Horne, into show business, wrote two multigenerational books about their ambitious Black middle-class family, died on July 18 at her home in Santa Monica, Calif. She was 86.

title: Elon Musk’s Transgender Daughter Says He Was ‘Cruel’ and ‘Uncaring’
description: Vivian Jenna Wilson, the transgender daughter of Elon Musk, said this week that her father had been “uncaring” and behaved in a “cruel” manner toward her as a child over her being queer and feminine.

title: Opening Ceremony Misses the Boat
description: Follow live updates of the women’s gymnastics qualifying at the 2024 Paris Olympics.

title: Doused by Rain, Paris Opens Its Games With a Boat Party on the Seine
description: In a blaze of French style blending history and artistic audacity, the Paris Olympic Games opened beneath plumes of blue, white and red smoke, as thousands of athletes defied a downpour to sail through the city’s heart, down the Seine toward the Eiffel Tower.

title: Snoop Dogg, NBC’s New Voice of the People
description: Once Snoop Dogg had waded through electrical cords on the floor and ambled his lanky frame around the disorderly equipment in a partially constructed television studio in Paris, he was able to peer out over a balcony overlooking the Eiffel Tower and survey the city he hopes to conquer during the Olympics.

title: Bullet or Fragment of One Struck Trump’s Ear, F.B.I. Says
description: The F.B.I. said on Friday that Donald J. Trump had been struck by a “bullet, whether whole or fragmented into smaller pieces,” providing the most definitive explanation to date about what injured the former president’s ear during an assassination attempt this month.

title: The Most Stylish Olympic Opening Ceremony Ever
description: Even before the XXXIII Olympiad officially began, the litany of firsts was enormous. The first Olympics in Paris in a century. The first with equal gender participation. The first opening ceremony, ever, en pleine air. The first sponsored by a global luxury behemoth.

title: Level, Essentially
description: SATURDAY PUZZLE — This is Barbara Lin’s Saturday debut, and it’s an achievement: She has now “hit for the cycle” as a New York Times constructor, meaning that she has created at least one puzzle for every day of the week. Matthew Stock, who shares credit for today’s grid, has accomplished this feat as well. He’s a prolific collaborator, so it’s perfect that he joined Ms. Lin as she took on the challenge of making a Saturday grid, as detailed in their notes below.

title: Trump, Honing Attacks on Harris, Casts Her as a Far-Left Threat
description: Former President Donald J. Trump sharpened his attacks against Vice President Kamala Harris on Friday, accusing her of wanting to impose left-wing values on the nation, painting her as overly liberal on immigration and abortion and calling her a “bum” in a speech to a gathering of religious conservatives.

title: Quotation of the Day: Rising Star of Surfing is at Peace, and on Roll
description: “When you’re on the wave, you’re very free. It’s an open canvas.”

title: No Corrections: July 27, 2024
description: Errors are corrected during the press run whenever possible, so some errors noted here may not have appeared in all editions.

title: The French Swimmer Who Is Carrying His Country on His Back
description: The French swimmer Léon Marchand understood that he would be his country’s marquee athlete at the Paris Games, and he surely is. Event workers stop him to sneak in selfies. A giant photo of him on the starting blocks adorns a skyscraper. Cameras are trained on him everywhere he goes.

title: Justice Dept. Defends TikTok Law That Forces App’s Sale or Ban
description: The Justice Department argued in a court filing on Friday that TikTok should be required to sell its American operations to resolve national security concerns about its Chinese parent company, ByteDance.

title: How a Drum Line Director Spends Her Sundays
description: For most of her life, Stacy Kovacs has been following the beat of the drum, which has led her to people and places she never anticipated.

title: You See Rubble and Garbage. She Sees New York’s Next Great Park.
description: The area under the Brooklyn Bridge in Lower Manhattan is a forbidding swath of rubble and construction equipment, cut off from the sky by six lanes of clattering bridge traffic. To most of the world, it communicates a single message: keep out.

title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.

title: A Digital Coin Based on Baby Trump? Yup.
description: Josh Bailey, a 26-year-old day trader in Austin, Texas, was scrolling through a cryptocurrency group chat last month when he encountered an investment opportunity: a digital currency created in honor of a dog named Billy.

title: Inside a Twister With the World’s Most Famous Storm Chaser
description: Every storm chaser has been looking forward to seeing the movie “Twisters,” a loose follow-up to the box-office smash “Twister” from 1996.

title: Park Fire in California Grows Dramatically, Becoming Largest Active Blaze in U.S.
description: The Park fire in Northern California has grown considerably to become the largest active blaze in the country, as firefighters raced on Saturday to contain scores of blazes across the American West.

title: To Uber, With Love
description: This is a happy story about a corporation you probably hate.

title: How Do You Solve a Problem Like Elon?
description: Late last year, Linda Yaccarino reached out to Don Lemon’s agent with an offer.

title: ‘No One to Talk To’: The Lingering Trauma of Russian Rape in Ukraine
description: After Daria fled from her Russian-occupied village to western Ukraine, she spent weeks restlessly wandering the streets. Whenever she grew tired of walking, she would sit on park benches and tell anyone who would listen — even perfect strangers — what the Russian soldiers did to her.

title: Beyond ‘Bridgerton’: 3 Steamy, Summery New Historical Romances
description: Most historical romance is solidly grounded in what I’ll call textbook history, where many narratives have been shaped by victors, politics and cultural currents. But this is the tyranny of convenience. At its most vital, historical romance also resurrects ephemeral yet utterly timeless truths: the sensations of the body beneath the clothing, the agonizing decision to burn letters brimming with illicit love.

title: The Right-Wing Dream of ‘Self-Deportation’
description: In his presidential campaign, Donald Trump has doubled down on bashing migrants crossing the southern border. They are criminals who are “poisoning the blood of our country,” he says. The Republican National Convention was full of talk of surging “migrant crime,” even though such a rise does not exist.

title: Away From the War in Gaza, Another Palestinian Economy Is Wrecked
description: Less than three years ago, Wassif Frahat spent $3 million to open a lavish, two-story restaurant, the Ali Baba. With an impressive, pillared entryway, polished stone floors, glittering chandeliers and colorful frescoes on the high ceilings, the restaurant was his commitment to a better future.

title: A Cross-Country Road Trip, With a Hidden Body in the Back Seat
description: When Mei Brown’s grandfather hands her the keys to a sedan purchased “with the savings from his life as a mechanic,” she sums up her current circumstance succinctly. “Her father had blown his brains out, she’d dropped out of an Ivy League school and her mother hated her. But Laoye had bought her a car.” With it he hands her an opportunity: clients (mostly sex workers) to drive around — and space from the life she’s trying to figure out.

title: Who Is Responsible for Fixing Condo Defects?
description: Q: We live in a newly constructed condominium in Manhattan. Last summer, we noticed dampness in the apartment and bought a humidity sensor that indicated the humidity in the unit to be 70 percent. We communicated with the management company through the fall, and they did some investigating, but the problem persists. We have installed a dehumidifier, but it’s loud and the reservoir needs to be emptied several times a day. What length of time is reasonable for the management company to address this? What else can we do?

title: Alanis Morissette Is Not Aloof
description: If Alanis Morissette’s albums were children, “Jagged Little Pill” would be the spoiled one — universally beloved, lavishly celebrated, extravagantly fed. She has a soft spot for her second born, “Supposed Former Infatuation Junkie,” which was reissued with new material last month for its 25th anniversary. (She plays from the album on her current tour, which has dates through September.)

title: JD Vance, an Unlikely Friendship and Why It Ended
description: When his book, “Hillbilly Elegy,” was published in 2016, JD Vance sent an email apologizing to a close friend from his Yale Law School days. The friend identified as transgender, but Mr. Vance referred to them in the book as a lesbian.

title: The 3 Biggest Mistakes You Can Make With Your 401(k)
description: In a surprising turn, given the usual grim reports about how little most Americans have saved for retirement, there’s been a spate of good news lately about 401(k) investors. Plan participation, contributions and account balances all were at or near record highs in 2023, according to a study last month from Vanguard. And new research from BlackRock shows that, buoyed by a surging stock market, nearly 70 percent of workplace savers now feel they’re on track for retirement — a 12 point jump from last year.

title: Sophia Roe’s Charm Earring
description: There are certain rules that Sophia Roe can’t seem to shake from her years working in restaurants: short nails, no nail polish, a separate sink to wash her hands.

title: What to Know About Kamala Harris’s Foreign Policy Positions
description: Hundreds of former Democratic foreign policy leaders this week backed Vice President Kamala Harris in her bid for the White House, vouching for their party’s presumptive nominee despite her limited experience in matters of diplomacy.

title: Lana Del Rey and Quavo Team Up
description: Jon Pareles, the chief pop music critic for The New York Times, recommends an unexpected collaboration, some guaranteed uplift, and more:

title: The Amiable Attack Dog From Kentucky Who Could Join the Harris Ticket
description: A political scion with the most famous last name in Kentucky Democratic politics, Andy Beshear, the affable, aw-shucks governor, is best known around the state for showing up.

title: Spoiler Alert: Here’s a Guide to the Cameos in ‘Deadpool & Wolverine’
description: “Deadpool & Wolverine” expects its audience to have a very good memory. To get the most out of the movie you have to not only be well-versed in the previous films starring the characters of the title — Ryan Reynolds’s foul-mouthed mercenary and Hugh Jackman’s gruff mutant with spiky claws — but you also should be able to recall the last 25 or so years of movies inspired by Marvel comic books. Even the ones that perhaps Marvel would like to forget.

title: 5 Excerpts From JD Vance’s Emails to a Transgender Classmate
description: As Senator JD Vance seeks the vice presidency, a former Yale Law School classmate and friend has shared about 90 of their emails and text messages, mostly from 2014 through 2017, with The New York Times.

title: More Trains, but Few Answers, After Railway Sabotage in France
description: In the dark early morning, they cut into a fence protecting the high-speed rail line right outside the small town of Croisilles. Once past the fence, the culprits soldered open the metal protective cover of a culvert alongside the tracks. Then, they poured flammable liquid and set a fire, damaging around 40 cables, explained the local mayor, Gérard Dué.

title: Pete Buttigieg Thinks the Trump Fever Could Break
description: This past month has been one of the most consequential and dizzying periods in modern American politics. It began with President Biden’s disastrous debate in late June. Then came an assassination attempt against former President Trump. A week later, President Biden dropped out of the race and endorsed his vice president, Kamala Harris. And now Harris is already the de facto Democratic nominee.

title: Olympics Results
description: The latest medal count and results for the Paris Olympics.

title: Kamala Harris Is Known Abroad for a Personal Touch, and Tough Talk
description: Like most vice presidents, Kamala Harris was not given much runway on foreign policy. President Biden prided himself on his international expertise and relished his rapport with global leaders. But in the role she did fill, Ms. Harris made an impression.

title: The Connections Companion No. 413, July 28, 2024
description: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.

title: Wordle Review No. 1,135, Sunday, July 28, 2024
description: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

title: Here’s the latest on the presidential race.
description: Vice President Kamala Harris acknowledged on Saturday that she had the delegates to win the Democratic nomination, but she cautioned her supporters about the road ahead, saying, “We are the underdogs in this race.”

title: The Olympics Have Arrived
description: It has been only three years since the last summer Olympics: the 2020 Tokyo Games, you’ll recall, were held in the summer of 2021. Time has been slippery since the pandemic began, anyway, even without reliable milestones moving around. Three years feels simultaneously like an eternity (think of how much has happened in the last three weeks) and a heartbeat (I’ve been just about to check out this playlist of “frat rock” recommended by Bruce Springsteen … for the past three Julys).

title: 24 Hours at the Golden Apple
description: On This Week’s Episode:

title: A New Wave
description: Michael February, a boundary-breaking surfer and the first Black South African on the World Surf League Championship Tour, embarks on a transformative journey.

title: How the Ocean Is Liberating for One of South Africa’s Best Surfers
description: I was born in 1993, just as apartheid was ending in South Africa. My father is an avid surfer who introduced me to the sport at a young age, and the freedom he felt in the ocean had a big impact on me. He faced challenges pursuing the sport, since it was historically reserved for white South Africans and beaches were segregated until 1989. But by the time I came around, things were changing. Being able to bring his son to the beach and into the water was something he’d always dreamed of. He’d always have a big smile on his face when we’d go surfing together, and he still does.

title: Reflecting on Biden’s Exit and His Legacy
description: To the Editor:

title: A.I. May Save Us or May Construct Viruses to Kill Us
description: Here’s a bargain of the most horrifying kind: For less than $100,000, it may now be possible to use artificial intelligence to develop a virus that could kill millions of people.

title: JD Vance, Purr-fectly Dreadful
description: Suddenly, Donald Trump looks enlightened about women.

title: Kamala Harris and the Audacity of Desperation
description: Across Donald Trump’s presidency, the American establishment achieved an unprecedented level of ideological unity and conformity — first in opposition to Trump himself, and then in the embrace of progressive ideology, in the “Great Awokening” that reached a crescendo in the hotter months of 2020.

title: How Kamala Harris Can Win
description: Kamala Harris has a lot to do in a short time — build a team, choose a running mate, introduce herself to the country. But her most important task is to figure out what this election should be about.

title: The Police Killing of Sonya Massey Argues for Alternatives to Reform
description: On July 6, Sonya Massey called 911 to report an intruder. After Sean Grayson, a sheriff’s deputy, and another officer found no intruder outside of her home in Sangamon County, Ill., they knocked on her door. The situation escalated after Ms. Massey went to turn off her stove. Within seconds Mr. Grayson drew his gun and shot her in the head.

title: I Was a Kamala Harris Skeptic. Here’s How I Got Coconut-Pilled.
description: I remember the moment I knew that Kamala Harris was not the candidate for me in the 2020 presidential race. It was just a few days before the second Democratic primary debate, and college student debt had become an issue on the campaign trail. Senators Bernie Sanders and Elizabeth Warren were promising large-scale, no-strings-attached relief to borrowers.

title: Chinese Swimmer Denies Cheating in First Public Comments on Doping Case
description: An Olympic swimming champion who was one of 23 Chinese athletes who tested positive for a banned substance before the last Summer Olympics said on Saturday that she and her teammates had been wrongly accused of doping and insisted that China would never allow any athlete to use performance-enhancing drugs.

title: Why Is It So Hard for Olympic Host Cities to Control Costs?
description: Follow live updates of the women’s gymnastics qualifying at the 2024 Paris Olympics.

title: New Israeli Evacuation Order in Gaza Displaces Palestinians Again
description: The Israeli army ordered the evacuation of several neighborhoods in southern Gaza on Saturday, the latest in a series of such directives recently that have forced tens of thousands of displaced Palestinians to relocate yet again.

title: Your Guide to Olympic Gymnastics: Balance Beam
description: Follow live updates of the women’s gymnastics qualifying at the 2024 Paris Olympics.

title: Your Guide to Olympic Gymnastics: Uneven Bars
description: Follow live updates of the women’s gymnastics qualifying at the 2024 Paris Olympics.

title: South Korea Reports Leak From Its Military Intelligence Command
description: South Korea was investigating a leak from its top military intelligence command​ that ​local news media said had caused a large amount of sensitive information, including personal data on the command’s agents abroad, to end up in North Korea, its military said Saturday.

title: Your Guide to Olympic Gymnastics: Floor Exercise
description: Follow live updates of the women’s gymnastics qualifying at the 2024 Paris Olympics.

title: Your Guide to Olympic Gymnastics: Vault
description: Follow live updates of the women’s gymnastics qualifying at the 2024 Paris Olympics.

title: Embattled Democrats Express New Hope With Harris at Top of Ticket
description: Senator Martin Heinrich, a two-term Democrat from New Mexico, was not on anyone’s watch list of incumbents facing serious re-election trouble given the reliable partisan tilt of his state, which has not voted for a Republican for Senate since 2002 or a Republican presidential candidate since 2004.

title: Blinken and a Top Chinese Official in Talks on U.S.-China Tensions
description: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken pressed his Chinese counterpart Saturday on areas of sharp disagreement between the two nations, including China’s support of Russia’s military industrial sector, the State Department said in a statement.

title: Trump Tells Christians ‘You Won’t Have to Vote Anymore’ If He’s Elected
description: In the closing minutes of his speech to a gathering of religious conservatives on Friday night, former President Donald J. Trump told Christians that if they voted him into office in November, they would never need to vote again.

title: Miso, Butter, Salmon
description: When I pitched this recipe for chan chan yaki — miso butter salmon — to Genevieve Ko, New York Times Cooking’s recipe wizard (and deputy editor), she lit up. “Three of my favorite things: miso, butter and salmon!” she said. And that’s how I feel, too, about this recipe that I adapted from one by Marc Matsumoto. (Marc’s a Tokyo-based food personality who, along with running his recipe blog, No Recipes, is a co-host of the charming “Bento Expo” show on NHK, Japan’s public broadcaster.) An easy dinner built on three flavorful, über-umami ingredients — what’s not to love?

title: Latino Leaders Set Aside Their Rocky Past With Kamala Harris on Immigration
description: No issue is likely to be thornier on the campaign trail for Vice President Kamala Harris, the presumptive Democratic presidential nominee, than immigration. Republicans are falsely painting her as President Biden’s failed “border czar” and running ads tying her to Biden administration policies that they argue have contributed to chaos at the border.

title: ‘All We Think of Is Him’: Putting Names and Faces to Bangladesh Carnage
description: A part-time tutor, shot in the neck and killed. A journalist and young father, felled by a bullet to the head. A shopkeeper’s son, also fatally shot in the head.

title: 2 Dutch Novels Plumb the Gulf Between Order and Chaos
description: Dear readers,

title: Peter Thiel, Elated by the JD Vance Pick, Warms to Trump Again
description: The Silicon Valley billionaire Peter Thiel’s relationship with Donald J. Trump turned ice-cold in the middle of 2023, when the former president excoriated Mr. Thiel on a private phone call over his unwillingness to support Mr. Trump’s re-election bid.

title: Rocket From Lebanon Kills at Least 12 in Israeli-Controlled Golan Heights
description: A rocket from Lebanon struck a soccer field on Saturday in the Israeli-controlled Golan Heights, killing at least 12 people, mostly teenagers and children, according to the Israeli military. It was the deadliest single attack from across Israel’s northern border in months of hostilities and raised fears of an escalation in the conflict.

title: 15-Year-Old Dies in Queens, Likely From ‘Subway Surfing,’ Police Say
description: A 15-year-old boy was found dead on a roadbed at a subway station in Queens on Friday. The boy, whom officials have not identified, most likely died as a result of so-called subway surfing, the police said.

title: Three Members of the Nelons Gospel Group Are Killed in a Plane Crash
description: Three members of the award-winning gospel band the Nelons and four other people on board were killed in a plane crash in rural Wyoming on Friday, according to the authorities and representatives for the band.

title: JD Vance Hits Back at Jennifer Aniston, Defending ‘Childless Cat Ladies’ Remarks
description: Senator JD Vance of Ohio, the Republican vice-presidential candidate, struck back at the “Friends” actress Jennifer Aniston after she criticized him for his past complaint that the nation was governed by “childless cat ladies,” including Vice President Kamala Harris.

title: Man Charged in Death Threats to Trump Trial Judge and Prosecutor
description: A man in Las Vegas has been charged with threatening to assault and kill federal officials, judges and state employees across several states, according to a federal indictment, including at least two people involved in the prosecution of former President Donald J. Trump.

title: Katie Ledecky’s relentless march toward history begins with a bronze in Paris.
description: Barring a shortage of chlorine in Paris, Katie Ledecky is likely to become the most decorated female swimmer in Olympic history at some point over the next two weeks, a distinction that has been suffused the last decade with all the suspense of a rom-com.

title: Despite Park Fire’s Rapid Spread, Some Residents Are Determined to Stay Put
description: As California’s biggest fire of the year raced toward his neighborhood and the police ordered residents to evacuate, Justin Freese decided he was going nowhere.

title: Harris Holds First Fund-Raiser as Democrats Rally: ‘We Are the Underdogs’
description: Vice President Kamala Harris warned a crowd of supporters on Saturday that former President Donald J. Trump held the advantage in their contest for the White House given the short window until Election Day.

title: California School Official Who Embezzled $16.7 Million Gets Nearly 6 Years in Prison
description: A former California public school official who embezzled more than $16 million from a school district and used the money to fund a lavish lifestyle was sentenced to nearly six years in prison this week, according to the Justice Department.

title: The Big 5-0
description: Jump to: Tricky Clues | Today’s Theme

title: Minnesota’s Governor, a Harris V.P. Contender, Calls Trump and Vance ‘Weird People’
description: In a potential audition to be Kamala Harris’s running mate, Gov. Tim Walz of Minnesota on Saturday cast former President Donald J. Trump and his vice-presidential pick, Senator JD Vance of Ohio, as a dangerous combination before their campaign visit to the state later in the day.

title: Elon Musk Shares Manipulated Harris Video, in Seeming Violation of X’s Policies
description: Elon Musk, the world’s richest man, has waded into one of the thorniest issues facing U.S. politics: deepfake videos.

title: The Move That May Take Sunisa Lee’s Name
description: Sunisa Lee has been practicing a new difficult element in her uneven bars routine. If she completes it at the Olympics, it will be named “The Lee.”

title: Echoes of the Fort McMurray Disaster as Fire Sweeps Into Jasper, Alberta
description: While I had covered many wildfires by 2016, I didn’t realize the full extent of their destructive energy until I stepped off a bus carrying journalists on the first official tour of Fort McMurray, during the tail end of a fire that had forced the panicked evacuation of the city.

title: California Highway Reopens After Lithium Battery Fire Trapped Drivers
description: A California highway reopened early Sunday after a fire involving an overturned truck carrying lithium-ion batteries trapped drivers in 109-degree heat for hours on Friday and Saturday.

title: Who Is Eminem for in 2024?
description: The 12th studio album by Eminem, “The Death of Slim Shady (Coup de Grâce),” just had its debut atop the Billboard album chart, 25 years after the rapper’s major-label debut launched him into the pop stratosphere.

title: JD Vance Stumbles in His Debut, as Democrats Go on Offense
description: The choice of Senator JD Vance as former President Donald J. Trump’s running mate reflected the confidence of a campaign so sure of victory in November that it could look beyond a second Trump term to the legacy of his movement.

title: Trump, Appealing to Bitcoin Fans, Vows U.S. Will Be ‘Crypto Capital of the Planet’
description: Former President Donald J. Trump vowed on Saturday that he would turn the United States into a “Bitcoin superpower" if returned to the White House, wielding much of the same rhetoric of persecution that he has applied to himself and his supporters to appeal to cryptocurrency enthusiasts who want to see less regulation.

title: Beshear, a Potential Harris V.P. Pick, Rallies Democrats in Deep-Red Iowa
description: Gov. Andy Beshear of Kentucky, in contention to be Vice President Kamala Harris’s running mate on the Democratic ticket, tried out for the post in Iowa on Saturday by going after the man he would face on the Republican ticket, telling Iowa Democrats that Senator JD Vance of Ohio has “contrived” his claims to be from Appalachia.

title: ‘Maybe I’ve Gotten Worse’: Trump Makes Clear That Unity Is Over
description: Early in his speech in Minnesota on Saturday night, former President Donald J. Trump made clear just how quickly he has jettisoned the appeal for national unity that he made after he survived an assassination attempt in Pennsylvania two weeks ago.

title: What’s on TV This Week: ‘Elizabeth Taylor: The Lost Tapes’ and ‘House of the Dragon’
description: For those who still enjoy a cable subscription, here is a selection of cable and network TV shows, movies and specials that broadcast this week, July 29-August 4. Details and times are subject to change.

title: Corrections: July 28, 2024
description: An article last Sunday about work by Wael Shawky described incorrectly the transfer of power in Egypt after Hosni Mubarak was deposed. Mohamed Morsi was elected, and then Abdel Fattah el-Sisi came to power. El-Sisi was not in power directly after Mubarak.

title: Quotation of the Day: Israeli Evacuation Order Displaces Gazans Again
description: “People aren’t being regarded as people. They’re being treated as pinballs and chess pieces.”

title: Fears of Escalation After Rocket From Lebanon Hits Soccer Field
description: Western diplomats were scrambling on Sunday to prevent a surge of fighting along the Israel-Lebanon border, officials said, after a rocket from Lebanon on Saturday killed at least 12 children and teenagers in an Israeli-controlled town. The rocket prompted Israel to retaliate early Sunday with strikes across Lebanon.

title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.

title: Marina Abramovic Wants to Live, Laugh, Love
description: Marina Abramovic stood and faced the ocean on Fire Island.

title: How the Shock of Catastrophic Floods Is Changing Farming in Vermont
description: When they bought their organic vegetable farm in South Royalton, Vt., slung along the fertile floodplain of the White River, Ashley Loehr and Antoine Guerlain took comfort in the dense buffer of shrubs and trees that lay between their fields and the gently swirling water.

title: ‘I Walked Right Into a Tree Branch, an Arm Extended Over the Sidewalk’
description: Dear Diary:

title: Simone Biles Is Done Being Judged
description: Follow live updates of the women’s gymnastics qualifying at the 2024 Paris Olympics.

title: Hollywood’s Message to Red States: Our Movies Are for You
description: For nearly two decades, Hollywood has seemingly missed no opportunity to sound the alarm about climate change.

title: Know What’s Funny About Getting Old? These Movies Do.
description: There are two new films this year in which Academy Award-nominated actresses in their 70s whip out tiny sex toys. In “Summer Camp,” Kathy Bates offers up wee vibrators to Alfre Woodard and Diane Keaton. In “The Fabulous Four,” it’s Bette Midler giving Susan Sarandon a kegel ball that she later flings at a bike thief.

title: At the N.R.A., a Battle Between the Old Guard and the New
description: The National Rifle Association’s new chief executive, Doug Hamlin, was elected only in mid-May, but he is already confronting a monumental obstacle.

title: Russia Punches Through Weakened Lines in Eastern Ukraine
description: Russian forces have made rapid gains in the eastern Donetsk region over the past week or so, capturing a few villages and closing in on the city of Pokrovsk, one of the main Ukrainian defensive strongholds in the area.

title: How Our Bodies Can Adapt to Heat
description: Inside a small, sealed room, Olivia Leach swallowed a pill that would soon monitor her internal temperature. She then hopped on a stationary bike and prepared to sweat. Slowly, as she began to pedal, the room started to heat up at a rate of one degree every five minutes.

title: Romeo and Juliet, Plus Guns, Cults and Waco, Texas
description: What is it about cults? We can’t seem to get enough of them, in whatever format — documentary, feature, series, news, memoir, fiction. We love these stories, I’d argue, for the same reasons people are drawn to cults themselves: the promise of a radical alternative, of emancipation from ourselves, of ideological cover for bad behavior, of simple (if theologically arcane) answers to life’s complex, intractable problems.

title: A Pedigreed Rail Magnate Is Pouring Millions Into Electing Donald Trump
description: Timothy Mellon, a wealthy banking heir and railroad magnate, has reached the stratosphere of American political influence as the top supporter of Donald J. Trump, doling out millions to try to elect the former president and his allies.

title: Racked by Pain and Enraptured by a Right-Wing Miracle Cure
description: Michael Chesebro awoke to the same reality as he did each morning, with pain radiating up his spine and into his shoulders before he opened his eyes. He remained still for a moment, summoning the courage to reach from his bed to his night stand. He rolled onto his back, which was fused together with metal after almost 20 years as a paratrooper in the military. He extended his arm, which he had broken several times while wrangling bulls and horses on his ranch outside Cheyenne, Wyo. Finally, his hand found his cellphone, and he logged on to the online universe where he spent most of his days.

title: A Memoir That Delivers on Its Promise of ‘Sex, Drugs, and Opera’
description: Even devotees of symphony orchestras sometimes struggle with the opera — its muchness and pomp. “The uproar,” my father called it, and he was a serious amateur chamber musician who collected and played the works of obscure composers on a Montagnana violin that he most certainly would have saved from a fire before my guinea pig, Percolator.

title: Business Is Buzzing Again for the Meme Makers of the Left
description: Last Sunday, after President Biden announced he was stepping down from his presidential campaign and endorsing Kamala Harris as his replacement, Democratic meme makers rejoiced.

title: The Lesser-Known Side of Harris’s Identity: Asian American
description: Daniel Chiang can remember one Asian American who ran for president in 2020: Andrew Yang, a Taiwanese American entrepreneur. But he was surprised to learn last week that there was another person running for president then, and in 2024, who counted herself an Asian American: Kamala Harris.

title: Kamala Harris’s Laugh Is a Campaign Issue. Our Comedy Critic Weighs in.
description: Kamala Harris has an easy laugh. To the campaign running against her, this appears to be a vulnerability to exploit.

title: Hourslong Lines as Voters Surge to Polls in Venezuela’s Pivotal Election
description: They arrived at polling stations long before dawn, slept in the streets so they could be the first in line, and then cried as they cast their votes.

title: The Quiet Bond Kamala Harris Forged With Three V.P. Contenders
description: When President Biden introduced Kamala Harris as his running mate four years ago, he shared their origin story: He had first learned of her, he said, through his son Beau, who served with her as a state attorney general.

title: ‘Deadpool & Wolverine’ Reverses Marvel’s Box Office Slump
description: Marvel Studios, trying to move past a pair of box office humiliations, deployed two of its most popular characters over the weekend and hit a mother lode.

title: Park Fire in Northern California Spreads to 360,000 Acres
description: The Park fire in Northern California has grown to more than 360,000 acres under less favorable weather conditions on Sunday, with fire activity picking up again, according to officials.

title: Melinda French Gates Is Ready to Take Sides
description: In May, Melinda French Gates said that she was leaving the Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation, which she helped found in 2000. Despite her divorce from Bill Gates a few years ago, the couple continued working together, and it was understood that Melinda was a crucial part of what made the foundation so effective. It’s hard to overstate what an earthquake her departure was in the world of big-donor charitable giving.

title: Wordle Review No. 1,136, Monday, July 29, 2024
description: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

title: Food as You Know It Is About to Change
description: This essay is part of What to Eat on a Burning Planet, a series exploring bold ideas to secure our food supply. Read more about this project in a note from Eliza Barclay, Opinion’s climate editor.

title: The Connections Companion No. 414, July 29, 2024
description: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.

title: Decoding JD Vance’s Brand of Nationalism
description: Is America an idea or a homeland? That question lies at the heart of this roller coaster of a presidential race. It’s about whether we Americans should continue to set our sights on global leadership and enforcing universal principles or instead hunker down and take care of our own.

title: The Sunday Read: ‘The Kidnapping I Can’t Escape’
description: On Nov. 12, 1974, Taffy Brodesser-Akner’s father’s childhood friend Jack Teich was kidnapped out of his driveway in the nicest part of the nicest part of Long Island. He was arriving home from work when two men forced him into their car at gunpoint and took him to a house where they chained and interrogated him.

title: 14 Questions About Our Leaders’ Health
description: There’s been enormous debate about the health of America’s president and that of the candidates for that job. Many questions remain unanswered.

title: Hulk Hogan Is Not the Only Way to Be a Man
description: The Democratic Party must join the battle for the hearts and minds of young men. It matters not just for this election, though the vast and growing gender gap means that disaffected men could hand Donald Trump the presidency. It matters for how we mentor young men, and it matters for how we view masculinity itself.

title: A Blood Test Accurately Diagnosed Alzheimer’s 90% of the Time, Study Finds
description: Scientists have made another major stride toward the long-sought goal of diagnosing Alzheimer’s disease with a simple blood test. On Sunday, a team of researchers reported that a blood test was significantly more accurate than doctors’ interpretation of cognitive tests and CT scans in signaling the condition.

title: Adapting to the Heat
description: It has been hot outside. Very, very hot.

title: As F-16s Arrive, Ukraine Still Faces Steep Challenges in the Skies
description: The surveillance drone appeared high above the Ukrainian air base without warning in early July. Minutes after it relayed targeting data back to a Russian base, a barrage of ballistic missiles struck the airfield, Ukrainian officials said, recounting the episode.

title: Here’s how Simone Biles and her American teammates stormed into the finals.
description: The U.S. women’s gymnastics team qualified for Tuesday’s team final with a solid performance on Sunday, led by Simone Biles — competing on a taped leg — and Sunisa Lee.

title: U.S. and Japan Announce Steps to Strengthen Their Military Ties
description: The top diplomatic and defense officials from the United States and Japan announced on Sunday that their nations would take concrete steps to bolster their military alliance because of the growing threat from China in the region.

title: Negotiators Meet to Revive Push for Hostage Release and Cease-Fire in Gaza
description: Senior officials from Israel, Egypt, Qatar and the United States met in Rome on Sunday to continue negotiations over a cease-fire in Gaza, according to three officials involved in or briefed on the talks and a statement from the Israeli government. The talks came as tensions mounted in the region amid growing violence along the border between Israel and Lebanon.

title: Grilled Chicken With Corn and Lime-Basil Butter, a Fantastic Taste of Summer
description: Good morning. One of the great American crossroads is the intersection of Route 82 and Church Street in Pine Plains, N.Y., where Clare de Boer has a restaurant, Stissing House. There’s a flatness there, a feeling of being at the center of a valley, as if you’re in a stream bed, the restaurant beside it, warm and old and clean. You’d like to ride a horse there and take a room upstairs to sleep after dinner.

title: An Olympics Scene Draws Scorn. Did It Really Parody ‘The Last Supper’?
description: A performance during the Paris Olympics’ opening ceremony on Friday has drawn criticism from church leaders and conservative politicians for a perceived likeness to Leonardo da Vinci’s depiction of a biblical scene in “The Last Supper,” with some calling it a “mockery” of Christianity.

title: Jill Biden, Jessica Chastain and Nick Jonas Toast Team U.S.A. in Paris
description: Just after 10 p.m. on Saturday night, on the first weekend of the Paris Olympics, Jill Biden walked through the wood doors of Ralph’s Restaurant Paris, past a towering display of red, white and blue flowers, and picked up two glasses of champagne from a silver tray.

title: Review: ‘The Righteous’ Brings Stirring Prayer to Santa Fe Opera
description: We’ve had “The Shining” and “Cold Mountain,” “The Hours” and “Dead Man Walking,” and works based on the lives of Steve Jobs, Malcolm X and Frida Kahlo. “Lincoln in the Bardo” and “The Amazing Adventures of Kavalier and Clay” are coming soon.

title: Harris Campaign Says It Raised $200 Million Since Biden Dropped Out
description: Vice President Kamala Harris’s campaign said on Sunday that it had raised $200 million in the week since President Biden withdrew from the race — more than Mr. Biden’s haul in the first three months of the year.

title: Edna O’Brien, Writer Who Gave Voice to Women’s Passions, Dies at 93
description: Edna O’Brien, the prolific Irish author whose evocative and explicit stories of loves lost earned her a literary reputation that matched the darkly complex lives of her tragic heroines, died on Saturday. She was 93.

title: Jill Schary Robinson, Who Wrote of Her Hollywood Upbringing, Dies at 88
description: Jill Schary Robinson, an author and journalist who limned her glittering, complicated Hollywood upbringing in much of her work, beginning with her wry 1963 memoir, “With a Cast of Thousands,” and who found fame for chronicling Hollywood’s darker side a decade later in “Bed/Time/Story,” died on July 19 at her home in Beverly Hills, Calif. She was 88.

title: It’s really a matter of math …
description: There are 10,000 athletes at the Paris Games, spread across 32 sports. In the space of 19 days, that field has to be whittled down to just 329 gold medals. So, ultimately, someone has to go out first. Here’s what it’s like to go first.

title: Video Shows Aftermath of Strike on Israeli-Controlled Golan Heights
description: Israel blamed Hezbollah, the Iranian-backed Lebanese military group, for an attack on a soccer field that killed 12 children and teenagers. Hezbollah has denied responsibility.

title: A Village’s Anguish Over 12 Children Lost to a Rocket Strike
description: The rocket struck on the sideline of the pint-size soccer field, just inside a chain-link fence, where the children of Majdal Shams, a picturesque Druse Arab village in the Israeli-controlled Golan Heights, wait their turn to play, or just sit and watch.

title: Robert Downey Jr. Set to Return to Marvel as Dr. Doom
description: Robert Downey Jr. is going from superhero to supervillain.

title: Toxic Families: Is Breaking Away the Answer?
description: To the Editor:

title: Gunman at Trump Rally Was Often a Step Ahead of the Secret Service
description: Nearly 100 minutes before former President Donald J. Trump took the stage in Butler, Pa., a local countersniper who was part of the broader security detail let his colleagues know his shift was ending.

title: James C. Scott, Iconoclastic Social Scientist, Dies at 87
description: James C. Scott, one of the world’s most widely read social scientists, whose studies on why top-down government schemes of betterment often fail and how marginalized groups subtly undermine authority led to his embrace of anarchism as a political philosophy, died on July 19 at his home in Durham, Conn. He was 87.

title: Behind a French roar, Léon Marchand leaves the world’s best swimmers in his wake.
description: The cheers for Leon Marchand thundered inside La Defense Arena on Sunday as he sat in the call room before the 400-meter individual medley, and then as he appeared in the pool area, as he was introduced in Lane 4, and then as he ascended the starting block, and, then, as he rocketed past seven other swimmers in the water with a ruthless, envious elegance.

title: 12 Officials Sentenced for Roles in Devastating Libya Flood
description: Twelve Libyan officials were convicted and sentenced on Sunday for their roles in a disaster that killed thousands of people and wrecked a huge swath of eastern Libya, the country’s top prosecutor said.

title: Remembering the Firebrand Irish Novelist Edna O’Brien
description: Decades before Elena Ferrante’s Neapolitan novels, the Irish writer Edna O’Brien — who died at 93 on July 27 — provided her own searing portraits of an oppressive, violent society seen through the prism of female friendship.

title: By the smallest of margins, Torri Huske won gold and healed an old heartbreak.
description: The gold medal that Torri Huske of the United States won on Sunday in the 100-meter butterfly barely eluded her three years ago at the Tokyo Olympics, a letdown that might not have annoyed her so much had she won silver then, or even bronze.

title: Monday Briefing: A Deadly Strike on the Israel-Lebanon Border
description: Western diplomats were scrambling to prevent a surge of fighting along the Israel-Lebanon border after a rocket from Lebanon killed at least 12 children and teenagers at a soccer field in an Israeli-controlled town on Saturday.

title: Quick Drive Around Town
description: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues

title: Adams Blocks Law That Bans Solitary Confinement in New York Jails
description: Mayor Eric Adams declared a state of emergency in New York City jails on Saturday and issued an executive order that blocked key parts of a local law that would have banned solitary confinement in the jails.

title: From Believers to Bitcoin: 24 Hours in Trump’s Code-Switching Campaign
description: In a matter of just 24 hours this weekend, Donald J. Trump traversed two very different worlds, neither one of them his own.

title: 3 Men With White Supremacist Ties Sentenced in Plan to Attack Power Station
description: Three men with white supremacist ties, including two former U.S. Marines, were sentenced to prison last week after plotting to destroy a power station in the northwestern United States, the U.S. Department of Justice said.

title: Venezuela’s Autocrat Is Declared Winner in Tainted Election
description: Venezuela’s authoritarian leader, Nicolás Maduro, was declared the winner of the country’s tumultuous presidential election early Monday, despite enormous momentum from an opposition movement that had been convinced this was the year it would oust Mr. Maduro’s socialist-inspired party.

title: ‘House of the Dragon’ Season 2, Episode 7 Recap: Soothing the Savage Beasts
description: Sometimes, in politics, a bold gamble in unprecedented times pays off. This is as true for the world of Westeros as it is for our own. The woman who wants to rule the realm staked it all on a long-odds play, and her odds came in.

title: Japan Wanted Higher Inflation. It’s Here, and It Hurts.
description: As the rest of the world fought to keep inflation in check, one country welcomed it with open arms.

title: Germans Combat Climate Change From Their Balconies
description: At a Berlin trade fair for sustainability, a new gadget caught Waltraud Berg’s eye — a solar panel small enough to be easily installed on the side of a balcony and then plugged into a wall socket to feed energy produced by the sun directly into her home.

title: Why Global Investors Are Watching What Japan Does Next
description: Japan’s central bankers meet this week, and what they decide has the potential to move markets around the world.

title: Why Some Olympic Swimmers Think About Math in the Pool
description: Kate Douglass, a statistics graduate student and the second-fastest swimmer in the world this year in two Olympic swimming events, has always been good with numbers. But before she enrolled at the University of Virginia, she never considered that swimming itself was a math problem that she could try to solve.

title: Pediatricians Warn Against Overuse of Tongue-Tie Surgeries
description: In recent years, more and more women struggling to breastfeed have taken their babies to a dentist to sever the tissue under the tongue.

title: Monday Briefing
description: Western diplomats have scrambled to prevent a surge of fighting along the Israel-Lebanon border after a rocket from Lebanon killed at least 12 children and teenagers on Saturday at a soccer field in a Druse Arab town in the occupied Golan Heights.

title: Word of the Day: ditty
description: The word ditty has appeared in 40 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on June 1 in “How Rhubarb Conquered Germany, Then the World” by Sarah Maslin Nir:

title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.

title: New York’s Preparations for a Bird Flu Pandemic Rely on a Single Drug
description: New York’s plan for confronting bird flu if it begins spreading among people relies heavily on a vast stockpile of flu treatment medicine. But experts worry the stockpile is missing a key tool.

title: Think N.Y.C.’s Roads Are Crowded? Good Luck on the Sidewalks.
description: This is Street Wars, a weekly series on the battle for space on New York’s streets and sidewalks.

title: No Corrections: July 29, 2024
description: Errors are corrected during the press run whenever possible, so some errors noted here may not have appeared in all editions.

title: Quotation of the Day: First Up, First Out
description: “It’s kind of a relief. Now you can really have fun and let loose.”

title: Here’s What to Know About Venezuela’s Flawed Election
description: President Nicolás Maduro was declared the winner in a presidential vote on Sunday that was marred by irregularities. Officials at some polling places refused to release paper tallies of the electronic vote count, and there were widespread reports of fraud and voter intimidation. Here are initial takeaways from Venezuela’s election.

title: Maduro Declared Winner in Flawed Venezuela Election
description: Venezuela’s presidential election was riddled with irregularities and was disputed by the opposition.

title: The Freedom of an Escape From Venezuela and the Loneliness That Followed
description: Jackson Villamarin Villegas moved into a third-floor walk-up apartment in the Sheepshead Bay neighborhood of Brooklyn in March. An immigrant from Venezuela, he shares the small room — and splits the $850 per month rent, plus utilities — with another migrant from his country.

title: In Oregon, a Bid for Urban Casinos Threatens a Gambling ‘Arms Race’
description: As the franchise owner of an Elmer’s family restaurant in southern Oregon featuring German pancakes “almost as big as Crater Lake” and omelets stuffed with local Tillamook Cheddar cheese, David R. Thomason has always tended to his customers, even before they walk through the front door.

title: Electric Cars Help the Climate. But Are They Good Value?
description: Electric vehicles cost more to buy than gasoline cars, and they may lose value more quickly. Even for people eager to own a car with no tailpipe emissions, it’s reasonable to wonder whether it makes sense to buy one now.

title: Traffic Enforcement Dwindled in the Pandemic. In Many Places, It Hasn’t Come Back.
description: The retreat by the police coincided with a surge in reckless driving and a rise in road fatalities.

title: 15 New Books Coming in August
description: Phillips’s latest is an unsettling story about technology gone awry. The novel follows a tech skeptic who must rely on the very A.I. she distrusts when her family comes under threat while on what is supposed to be an offline vacation.

title: A New Path in Tuscany Offers Rest, Beauty and an Escape from the Crowds
description: In Tuscany, the Val d’Orcia, with its rolling fields and untouched landscape beneath the dormant volcano of Monte Amiata, seems created for photo ops. Within it, the town of Pienza is one of the finest examples of Renaissance architecture, designed by the famed Bernardo Gambarelli, better known as Bernardo Rossellino, in white travertine marble and surrounded by palazzi which he also built.

title: Test Your Skills as a Games Moderator
description: Try your hand at the behind-the-scenes work that goes into the Games community forums.

title: More States Are Passing Book Banning Rules. Here’s What They Say.
description: While the effort to restrict access to books has been getting somewhat less attention on the national stage, it remains a potent issue on the state and local level, where most decisions about schools and libraries are made.

title: Swish, Spit, Repeat: Is Oil Pulling Good for Your Teeth?
description: In a video on TikTok, a woman scoops a heaping spoonful of solid coconut oil out of a jar and stuffs it into her mouth. She explains how she swishes the oil around — pushing and pulling it between her teeth — for about 10 minutes. Then, she spits it into the trash. She does this two to three times a week, she said.

title: New York Is Fed Up With a Deluge of Unpaid Water Bills
description: Good morning. It’s Monday. We’ll look at the latest chapter in the city’s crackdown on unpaid water bills. We’ll also find out about a plan to reopen a landmark movie theater on the Upper West Side.

title: Iowa’s 6-Week Abortion Ban Takes Effect
description: Iowa’s ban on abortions after roughly the sixth week of pregnancy took effect on Monday morning, changing the map of abortion access in the Midwest and giving Republicans in the state a long-sought policy victory.

title: There’s a New Reason to Save Life in the Deep Ocean
description: To most of us, the ocean is a no man’s land — a vast, bottomless and uncharted void. Three-quarters of the ocean has never been seen by humans, and only a quarter of its floor has been mapped in detail, which means we have a better understanding of the surface of Mars than we do of the seas on our own planet. It is this lack of exploration and appreciation — particularly of the layer of cold, dark water that begins where light fades, known as the ocean’s twilight zone — that has led us to a very precarious place.

title: Baldwin’s ‘Blues for Mister Charlie,’ 60 Years After It Hit Broadway
description: One spring day in 1964, among the glittering theater marquees of Times Square, James Baldwin was en route to rehearsal for his new Broadway production, “Blues for Mister Charlie,” and he’d had a lot on his mind. Four little girls had been killed in a church bombing in Birmingham, Ala., just months earlier, and the white producers of his play had been after him to soften the script, suggesting it might be inappropriate for Broadway. By the time he reached the theater, he was furious.
